<answer>



I've never knowingly been blocked. However, I felt that I had to block someone the other day -- someone who only ever answered my questions (I being her only contact) and who was becoming increasingly abusive. I am prepared to put up with healthy debate and crossing swords with people who hold different views from my own, but I don't see why I have to put up with arrant rudeness from someone who doesn't make any attempt to understand the question or give any thought to a providing a reasonable answer.



I hope that I never have occasion to block anyone else. Maybe this person can start answering other people's questions, in which case it will have been worthwhile.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



I don't honestly know if anyone has blocked me or not.  I wouldn't care if I was though.  Not everybody is going to like me, I'm bound to offend someone sometime.  I can just honestly say that I'm sorry if I do offend someone and if they want to block me, it's fine by me.  I could not care less.  To each his own!  :-D



Life is too short to worry about silly stuff and silly people who feel they have to "show you" by blocking you...HA!  It just seems infantile to me.



Edit:  Haha  That blocking cap reminds me of a childhood song:



"Everybody hates me, no body likes me, I guess I'll go eat worms!"



I'm sorry, that silly song always makes me laugh and remember how silly it all really is.



</answer>

shadylan...

<question>



Have you  ever been actuality stuck in the mud?



i have often heard the expression "don't be a stick in the mud" well my friend lenny and i were mushroom hunting one spring (the eating kind not the magic ones ok) and had to cross a plowed field it had been raining so about half way across we found our selves sinking way past our knees, we were stuck we ended up losing our shoes had to sort of slither crawl to get out took us for ever by the time we got to his car we were covered from head to toe in mud lenny had lost his keys but being 16 we were laughing so hard we could hardly breath blaming each other over whose idea it was to shortcut across the field we hot wired his car and was driving back to to town when a county sheriff  pulled us over for speeding he walked up to the car looked at us started laughing and shaking his head told us to slow down and then just let us go,,,,,, man i love a small town (1967)



</question>

<question from>



Genie
Member since: 02 February 2008
Total points: 4090 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



When voting, did you have to show your ID?



Here in Wyoming, we didn't.  We just signed our name.  Seems like one could vote more than once if so inclined.



</question>



<additional details>



I just told them my name; then my address.  I did not have to show them anything.



I never received a voter registration card nor was I asked to present one.



Yes, they looked up my name,  but how do they know that it is actually ME that is standing before them?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Suzianne
Member since: 11 May 2006
Total points: 10771 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Here in Arkansas, we were told to bring ID to the polling place...A drivers license, utility bill or any documentation that confirmed our name and address.  We presented our ID and the clerk found our name on the voter's list which contained a facsimile of our signature, next to which we signed our names.  It was quick and simple and assured each voter that his or her vote would not be diluted by fraudulent voters.



I would recommend the system to other states.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for all of your answers.  This one was the most thorough.  I like the fact that you had to sign next to your own previous signature along with bringing some sort of proof of identification.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Jackie



Blue
Member since: 11 August 2007
Total points: 17204 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the problems that arise are so easily remedied. The voting process isn't rocket science, but you would think so. Why can't every polling place do the exact same thing. It's not wonder there is confusion. It should be required by all polling stations to ask for a valid picture ID, period. Common sense doesn't seem to prevail. The church where we voted had lines going in all directions, and had moved the location to a smaller building. It was ridiculous, knowing there would be a bigger vote turnout this time. Make you wonder sometimes doesn't it? I bet elementary kids would have better sense that what goes on.



</answer>



<answer from>



leftcoas...
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 2484 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



No.  I voted absentee & mailed it in about 12 days ago.  It did require my signature.  They check all the signatures on the envelopes of mail-in ballots before counting.  Most of them are checked before election day.



In our county, I think we have almost 50% who are on permanent absentee status & always vote by mail-in ballot.  Almost everyone at work voted a couple of wks ago, after much discussion of the measures.  It's very convenient.  If we don't get them mailed in time, we can take our ballots to the polls or to other places at designated times.



Didn't they look up your name & check you off when you signed?



</answer>



<answer from>



gracie
Member since: 21 May 2007
Total points: 6205 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



We had to have photo ID's (drivers license) here in my part of GA. And while one worker took and checked over my voter registration card, another told my husband they weren't necessary when he presented his!



Until reading your question and the other answers, I didn't realize how differently it's all handled, depending where you live.



</answer>

<question from>



Miz D
Member since: 19 June 2007
Total points: 13446 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



Why is naught zero?  Can anyone explain?



But if you are naughty you are being bad?



</question>



<answer from>



Nicole B
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 281 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Naught by definition means of no importance or reason. However, the term naughty was derived from this word b/c of acting badly without reason.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I think I understand the meaning of the words now.  Thank you for your answer.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Sew What?
Member since: 26 July 2007
Total points: 9314 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question from>



redcore8...
Member since: 31 March 2008
Total points: 94 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why is mister ed so hostile?



This guy used have really good answers, but now it is just about insulting others



</question>



<answer from>



Old Guy
Member since: 12 May 2006
Total points: 5986 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I don't know Mr. Ed that well, but I do remember being very favorably impressed with one of his answers a long time ago and writing to him about it.  He did point out (at that time) that he could be a little short with people at times.  Ha ha.  I guess from your question, that he was accurate about that assertion.  I guess, because of having experienced his friendlier side for a while, you might now be feeling that his temperament has changed.  I doubt that it really has.  I think he's the same old guy, but is currenly just running into a spurt of questions that get under his skin, and you're now getting to see the shorter side of his temper.  None of us are loving angels all the time.  And I doubt that Mr. Ed would ever classify himself as a loving angel any of the time.  He's, in my humble opinion, probably more of a "matter-of-fact" kind of guy.  And by that I mean, if you write yourself a financial plan, and you follow it, you won't have to worry about crying poor-mouth later.  We all have our days when people can bring us to the end or our wits because no matter how hard we try to help them with common sense advice, they keep repeating the same mistakes.  One such mistake is living outside our means.  The people who are cursed with that problem are doomed to be crying poor-mouth until they die.  That's the way it'll be if they don't learn to live within their means, and foolishly insist on trying to project an image of affluence while living among their poor neighbors.  Who do they think they kidding?  Their neighbors certainly know they are putting on a phoney front.  I think it's these types who wear down Mr. Ed's patience and move him to allowing his temper to flare.



Two of the categories that Mr. Ed focuses on are Credit and Personal Finance.  Those have to be the categories that "affluent-wanna-bees" most likely hang out in to cry about how their poor financial state is due to the government being stingy with social security money, etc.  The truth be known, their situation is most likely because of poor planning on their part.  And I say "most likely" because I know that there are situations where little old ladies are left out to struggle by men who've taken financial advantage of them by leaving them penniless.



Because I'm not on YA very often anymore, I've taken the time to check out Mr. Ed's profile, and I was very impressed with his numbers.  This guy has a 43% Best Answer record.  And two thirds of his answers are in the Credit category and Personal Finance category.  Those two categories are notorios for cry-babies who can't admit that they've got to get serious about how they handle their finances.  For some reason, they think the government should supply them with whatever extra money they believe they need to live the life style they feel they deserve.



So, my recommendation, and I hope I don't come accross as preachy, is to give Mr. Ed a little slack when he goes through spurts of venting over the frustrations one can experience over trying to help people who won't help themselves.



There's one such lady on pipes up here on Seniors every once in a while who got a student loan to get a better education and earn a better living during her work years, and I'm assuming did well income wise, but spent beyond her means and decided not to pay her student loan back to the government (thinking she could get away with it because others were saying the were getting away with it.)  Well, ha ha. The government got her in the end.  The government is now deducting those long overdue student loan payments from her social security benefits.  I suspect trying to survive is a real bear for her now.  And although I have sympathy for women who were financially abused by their husbands, I have none for the likes of the lady who chose not to pay back her student loan.



I don't think Mr. Ed would care about her either.  What about you?  Would you feel sorry for the lady who didn't pay her student loan?  Mr. Ed hears such stories a lot, and I can understand his reluctance to show sympathy.  So, I think this might be part of why Mr. Ed might sound a little hostile at times.  Just a good guy affected by frustration over his efforts to help others I think.



</answer>

<question from>



shadylan...
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 350 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Have you  ever been actuality stuck in the mud?



i have often heard the expression "don't be a stick in the mud" well my friend lenny and i were mushroom hunting one spring (the eating kind not the magic ones ok) and had to cross a plowed field it had been raining so about half way across we found our selves sinking way past our knees, we were stuck we ended up losing our shoes had to sort of slither crawl to get out took us for ever by the time we got to his car we were covered from head to toe in mud lenny had lost his keys but being 16 we were laughing so hard we could hardly breath blaming each other over whose idea it was to shortcut across the field we hot wired his car and was driving back to to town when a county sheriff  pulled us over for speeding he walked up to the car looked at us started laughing and shaking his head told us to slow down and then just let us go,,,,,, man i love a small town (1967)



</question>



<additional details>



this is just one of many i could tell you about the adventures with lenny



</additional details>



<answer from>
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 6014 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



i was 16 and what my friend and i were doing in a pasture in the middle of the nite i have no idea but im sure chemicals of some sort were involved. Well I got the idea to use the jack cause we were in it up to the back bumper. needless to say with no solid ground for the jack, my shoes already gone, she and i walked about a quarter of a mile to my house...woke everyone of course. Took me two days to get that oklahoma red clay off my feet. i'll save for driving into the edge of a man made lake hole for another time. i have a lot of stories with me and chemicals. lol



</answer>

<answer>

I always would walk upstream while he fished and once found myself in a sticky situation. I thought I was in quicksand and about to die. The scream I let out brought him on the run, only to laugh at me, there in the mud up to my knees, all over my clothes and face.  Being my hero, he saved me from the mud monster.  We often laughed about it for  years.



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk112039.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Cultures & Groups



</category>



<question from>



NanaT
Member since: 25 February 2008
Total points: 3722 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Has this ever happened to you?



TWO DIFFERENT DOCTORS' OFFICES



Boy, if this doesn't hit the nail on
the head, I don't know what does!



Two patients limp into two different
medical clinics with the same complaint.  Both have trouble



walking and appear to require a hip replacement.



The FIRST patient is examined within the
hour, is x-rayed the same day and has a time booked for
surgery the following week.



The SECOND sees his family doctor after



waiting 3 weeks for an appointment, then waits 8 weeks to



see a specialist, then gets an x-ray, which isn't



reviewed for another week



and finally has his surgery scheduled for



6 months from then.



Why the different treatment for the two



patients?



The FIRST is a Golden Retriever.



The SECOND is a Senior Citizen.



Next time take me to a vet!



And it's going to get worse if we have social medical care...*sigh*



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I haven't had that experience. But I know that what you say is true. I've heard and read many articles on this subject.



</answer>

<answer>



Here in S.C., they have the electronic voting machines. This was my second time using them, & it's so much easier & faster than using the paper ballot. The first time I used them, I asked for help, & they were very nice in assisting me. I explained that in the north where I voted, they didn't have the electronic machines. This year, I needed no help. The line was long........behind me. I went early, knowing what I'd run into. Glad I did.

<answer from>



Barbara B
Member since: 16 January 2007
Total points: 14146 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I used the paper ballot - mostly for the novelty of it. It was nearly the size of a bath towel it was so huge - well over standard legal size. I was so amused that anyone would consider a paper ballot anymore. I just couldn't resist.



I live in a rural part of the country and even there, I could have used an electronic device - but after decades of using "machines" to cast my ballots, I simply couldn't resist marking a real X next to my choices.



However, in the future, I would not be averse to returning to technology to vote. Just so I CAN vote. That's the whole premise isn't it? Not the medium used.



Fortunately the lines were short although the polling judges said that there had been a record turnout - and this was in the middle of the afternoon.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What would you do if you..?



If you were asked to do something so out of your box to say.and you knew they were serious.and you found yourself doing it,Has anyone been there,



</question>



<answer from>



WACVET75
Member since: 18 May 2007
Total points: 11185 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It of course would depend, as long as it was something I could do considering the physical shape I'm in, and wasn't illegal. I may be older but I'm not gone yet and doing things "out of your box" will help keep you young. You must exercise your mind to stay sharp, as well as exercise the body, and what the heck, I'll try it and if I like it I may do it again. I do have some friends that can still cook up some strange things to do, I used to be the instigator, but have passed that title on. I still get involved though and sometimes it turns out to be great fun.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Love to hear some of those wild things do tell..vbs



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



HappyCam...
Member since: 06 February 2007
Total points: 9022 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>

I've done many things that I didn't feel comfortable with that turned out to be good and sometimes not so good.I guess I'd have to know what was expected of me and what I'd be willing to do.  It really all depends on when, where, and with whom I guess.Not much of an answer but what come to mind.



</answer>

<question>



Have you met someone on YA, who wanted to be friends, but dropped you without saying why?



after exchanging a few e-mails?  This happened to a friend of mine & she feels badly, as the woman wanted her friendship, then vanished. I told my friend that the woman was never a friend in the first place. My friend has seen that so called friend's Q's & A's to other people since all contact with her ceased.  Your thoughts please?



</question>



<additional details>



I spoke with my friend after I posted this question & I asked her what the e-mails these two shared, were about. She said they spoke of pets, family, weather, & chit chat things. I know my friend well enough to know she wouldn't say anything to hurt anyone. She's a rare friend & we treasure each other's  friendship.



Dee Jay....I understand your reasons for being cautious.



:)



Doncaster..Good for you!



</additional details>



<answer from>



DeeJay
Member since: 24 July 2006
Total points: 20035 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Senior Citizens



</answer from>



<answer>



I was in the process of making contacts, but when I opened my email public - I got some horrendous emails and had to close and go private, but I did inform my friends/contacts and I hope to try connecting again at a later time.



The situation you are speaking of - makes you wonder why.



I hope everyone on seniors, don't mind me feeling like I have friends here.



I just need to be cautious for the time being, while it is checked out.
Good question
DeeJay.



</answer>



<answer from>



Doncaste...
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 1173 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



last week was the first time i accepted 2 people from y/a to have email correspondence with (prior to that i did not know about fanbox or how it worked) and still not really sure.  to date neither of the 2 have replied.
it does not bother me, as i generally only use y/a for my entertainment - polls/jokes - and to assist with advice when i think that i can help from what i know or have experienced during my life,but even then i got a violation for telling the truth.



have a happy day s.t.



</answer>



<answer from>



Harry
Member since: 03 August 2006
Total points: 18166 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is how the internet is. People seem to forget that whoever they are conversing out there with is an actual person. And sometimes they do things with online they would never do in realtime with friends.  Then too, there are those out there who do not understand that some people see the written word (e-mail, letters, cards, etc.) as tools to cultivate a friendship.  To them, friendship is only dependent upon doing things with each other in realtime or conversing with each other in realtime.  Dropping people from their friendship list does not have any effect on these folks.



Once "burned," all of us seem to learn what to expect out of this form of communication.  It is sometimes a difficult lesson to take though.



Good luck to your friend.



Source(s):



Been there.



</answer>



<answer from>



caraohar...
Member since: 12 July 2007
Total points: 2286 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had this happen to me also ..although it wasn't on here. We exchanged email for some months..just like your friend, chit chat about different things but we did have one thing in common...which was an illness with one of our children. She just stopped emailing me even though I did try contacting her . I tried to think what it was I said to offend her...over time I began to realise she really didn't have the same sense of humour as myself...so maybe I made a joke of something she said in an email... that's the only thing I could come up with. Show your friend these answers and I'm sure she will realise she is not the only one that has had to deal with this sort of thing. Let her know there are really, good, kind, thoughtful people out there.



</answer>

<question>



Is there a food bank for pets?

I am aware of the category I have chosen.

<answer from>



gerlawgo...
Member since: 09 August 2006
Total points: 7931 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



I have never heard of one, but I know a girl that appealed to the humane society locally when her family took the money she had for pet food. They gave her food to last her through until the next month.



Another Idea, you could start one, get donations from your friends, or buy at dollar tree or big lots and give by referral only, such as by church, humane organization, or regular food pantry, so that you are not taken advantage of.



Good Luck, God Bless You.



You may also wish to post in community service for more ways to make your idea work.

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



What are your thoughts on Michelle Obama's dress last night?



I thought it was very unusual, not the normal kind you would see on THE night your husband is elected President. Watching all these months, both Michelle and Cindy McCain were both very classy dressed so I was a little shocked. If it were me, I would have picked either a Navy Blue, Royal Blue, Red Suite, or even an autumn color. If I remember correct, Cindy had on a Gold or Yellow suite. I have respect for each lovely lady. I just wanted to know what you thought. Thank you ahead. (Why is Yahoo picking Sports &gt; Golf for this question? That's strange. So if Yahoo can pick that catagory, then I can pick Seniors catagory. lol).



</question>



<answer from>



Moon Raker
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 933 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Me-She
Member since: 25 March 2006
Total points: 29815 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



In Central California we have gangs (black gangs) sporting the colors of red & black.  It certainly was a shock to see the entire family dressed in those colors.  In fact, it just reinforced the fact that the Obama family seems to lack what is needed in the white house.  I hope they can learn quickly & catch on that they are no longer just regular "folk".  It's time to step it up a notch & learn some of the finer things in life in order to stay in those circles of the other worldly Royals!



I thought they looked like someone else planned the outfits for them.  If so...that person should be fired ASAP!



Edit:  It's essential that the new first family understands that they really DO have an impact on their own race & what they wear has the ability to send a message to a part of life that they may not even realize exists!  That was my main point.  I enjoy those TD's.  It tells me that many are in denial over racial tension & boundary lines that currently still do exist in 2008.



</answer>



<answer from>



Diana
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 3194 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with you.

Oh well, I suppose her dress is really unimportant right now.



I just couldn't help but wonder about it.



</answer>

noonecan...
Member since: 10 October 2006

</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>

YA aside I haven't really heard anyone in the real world complaining about the results. So I have to think that it wasn't really all that Black and White (By the way this doesn't mean I'm right). Additionally it's a very well known fact that most voters (all colors) vote for charisma, now that should be a heart breaker I would suspect. In a crunching moment, well actually dozens of them, I have spoken with co-workers and many friends, who have a firm commitment to vote for someone and can't, with any kind of conviction, intelligence or in plain english tell me why, other than they will either 1.) end the war or 2.) end the financial crisis. And that's not to mention how many Americans don't even understand the electoral vote or have a clue about most of the Constitution Articles or any Amendments. So when you comment on the Black voter you really are describing the intelligence level of most American voters Black and White.



When I think back to Nixon's second term (This is the guy that promised to get us out of Viet Nam during his first term campaign) it astounds me that people take their concerns to the level they do these days regarding Obama or Palin and there experience level. According to the constitution you need only be a natural born citizen and 35 years old to run for president in the United States. So how do you determine who would be best for the country, regardless of what you saw or heard it's only a snap shot in time, and time changes everything,.

<answer>



During the campaign, I watched carefully as two candidates performed under tremendous pressure.  One remained calm and stuck to the campaign and issues at hand; the other became frustrated and frazzled and allowed his campaign to spin out of control into one mudslinging sound byte after another.  I said to myself, "Which one will be the best diplomat to solve the problems of our nation?"  And you know what? I chose Obama because he has proven the ability to stand strong and get the job done.



Race had nothing to do with my choice, but I'm actually glad that our country has finally broken the race barrier by electing a non white as president.  It sends a message to the world that we indeed can work together as truly United States.  I think that if he chooses his cabinet as well as he chose his campaign team, he'll prove to be one of the best presidents in history.



There is all kinds of anecdotal evidence that you can dig out to prove your racism theory, but one fact remains:  Obama couldn't have won without significant numbers of votes from white voters.  I believe that I heard that 42% of white women voted for Obama.  So you see, it's not just a black thing.  It's an American thing.



</answer>

<question>



Seniors' what lessons have you learnt in your long life,?



Mine is......a person's greatness is evidenced by his deeds and not by his words or feelings  [Maria Faustina]



</question>



<answer from>



suburban
Member since: 11 March 2006
Total points: 3674 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



make like a duck------calm and serene on the top, but paddle like mad underneath.



</answer>



<answer from>



Von Ryan
Member since: 29 April 2008
Total points: 1437 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not quite a "senior",but what i would say is I've learned that, no matter what happens, how bad it seems today, life does go on, and it will be better tomorrow.



I've learned that you can tell a lot about a person by the way he/she handles four things: a rainy day, the elderly, lost luggage, and
tangled Christmas tree lights.



I've learned that, regardless of your relationship with your parents,
you'll miss them when they're gone from your life.



I've learned that making a "living" is not the same thing as making a
"life.."



I've learned that life sometimes gives you a second chance.



I've learned that you shouldn't go through life with a catcher's mitt
on both hands. You need to be able to throw something back.



I've learned that if you pursue happiness, it will elude you. But if
you focus on your family, your friends, the needs of others, your work
and doing the very best you can, happiness will find you.



I've learned that whenever I decide something with an open heart, I
usually make the right decision.



I've learned that even when I have pains, I don't have to be one.



I've learned that every day, you should reach out and touch someone.



People love that human touch -- holding hands, a warm hug, or just a
friendly pat on the back.



I've learned that I still have a lot to learn.!



</answer>



<answer from>



rhymingr...
Member since: 28 February 2006

Be kind to others.  You never know how much someone else needs a smile, or a hug.  You could save someone with a smile.



You get more cooperation being kind than you do by being a b*tch!  If you are nasty to someone, they aren't going to help you no matter how right you are.



For most people, the only thing that matters is the bottom line.  The bottom line is always money.  And that is a sad, sad fact.



I've learned that for me, the only things I value are:



My family and pets
God
PEACE & NO dramatics
Friends



As long as the above is ok...NOTHING else matters a damn.

<answer>



1.  I'm never going to be first in line on the highway, so I might as well go the speed limit.



2.  If at first you don't succeed, make sure that it's worth trying again before you do it.  Don't waste your time on stupid stuff.



3.  If someone is looking for an argument, make it hard for them to find it.



4.  There's nothing more important than family.



5.  Don't make promises you can't keep.



6.  Save for a rainy day, but don't save so much that you don't enjoy your life.



7.  Don't buy stuff that you can't afford.



8.  Look for the good in all people, but don't be blind to their faults.



9.  If you're wrong, admit it.  Someone always finds out.



10. Trust your own instincts.  If you have a bad feeling about something, you're probably right.



</answer>

<question>



Are all states in the US  "dry" on election day?



</question>



<additional details>



Dry meaning no alcohol sold or served.



Or dry meaning the weather! :)



I give thumbs up to all who answer.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Loren S
Member since: 27 August 2007
Total points: 21533 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



see this link for further information;  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcohol_law...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks Loren!  Gee.. I thought the liquor laws were strange here!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



folklore
Member since: 23 May 2006
Total points: 6614 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I fondly remember as a young child, the only time my Dad would be home right after work was on election day. My parents were avid voters, one a democrat and one a republican and they would go together(Mom didn't drive or have a car)to vote after Dad got home. Every other work day Dad would stop at, what they called, a beer garden for an hour. So when Dad was home early(actually on time) from work, I knew it was to vote. That was Pennsylvania back in the 50's, don't know now.



</answer>



<answer from>



meerkat uno
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 3318 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



No.  I think it is just states that tend to be "dry" for other things.  Here in Michigan we are only dry from 9:00 PM Christmas Eve to 6:00 AM December 26th and every Sunday from 2:00 AM to noon.  There are several counties that are dry all day Sunday,too.  I think it is more a township or county thing rather than a state thing.



</answer>

<answer from>



Just Joyce
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 8427 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



LOL. . Yes, I will honestly admit to being a Wuss ! No offense taken here Tink.  You mentioned not being around lately, so let me answer your question this way. . . A wuss according to the dictionary is a weakling, a chicken, a wimp, someone who is afraid. . . One thing that makes me afraid is being expelled from Yahoo Answers . . . I love this site !.  The rules state that after so many violations (no amount given) your account will be deleted, and you will loose the privilege of being a Yahoo member. These violations come from questions and answers that are considered "chatting" etc. and just last month I received 9 of them.  Half were appealed and reinstated.



You will notice that some of the regulars are gone, or possibly under a new name. A lot are just reading and not participating due to the amount of violations being given.  So, using this criteria, yes, I am a wuss. . . I now try to answer carefully because of all the hoopla !



</answer>

What kind of personality is best to be a carer for the elderly?

</question>



<answer from>



Autumn Leaves
Member since: 27 June 2008

</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Nettie
Member since: 15 March 2006
Total points: 25896 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



What a caring person you must be to ask such a question. Not everyone has the right personality or apptitude to be a carer of anyone let alone the elderly.



I would say that patience, humour, stamina and understanding are the most important attributes.



Shyness well you'll soon come of your shell, lol Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



tink
Member since: 15 June 2007
Total points: 1276 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Compassionate and empathetic personality with a sense of humor and a great big heart. I know that when my time comes, I will be very fortunate to have a caregiver with these virtues...I think you have to be a special person to do this kinda work but good caregivers are few and far between so I say go for it. However, you may be the only contact to the outside world this person has so it's a Very important job, paid or not.
You being shy, in my opinion, should'nt be a negative at all. Anyway, you'll only be shy for a little while till you get to know your charge. It may even enable the elderly person to feel useful in helping you out of your shell. Good Luck and God bless!



</answer>



<answer from>



ROXY.sheila from oz.
Member since: 12 August 2007
Total points: 8470 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



u won't be shy for long working with elderly people .the attributes u need are empathy, PATIENCE, good humour, a desire to do this job.i think u have most of those already.the nuts 'n' bolts of it u will learn. good luck .
ps elderly people are like everybody else, different personalities, so u don't need to be a certain type to be good at this job .



</answer>



<answer from>



waggy
Member since: 10 April 2006
Total points: 14239 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



To be a carer you need to be patient and friendly.  Nonjudgmental and don't jump to conclusions or assumptions about people.  Be a good listener, not just to what people say, but to how they are as individuals.  Everyone is different with their experiences and what they need from a carer. so don't be hurt if a person does get frustrated with you.  I t might not be you personally, more the situation they are in.  it is an incredibly important job and if you are willing to persevere, there's no reason why you shouldn't make a really good carer!



</answer>

<question from>



Resi
Member since: 03 January 2008
Total points: 8382 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



How can you add a contact , then go back to private with out loosing them?



</question>



<answer from>



Imaka
Member since: 14 February 2006
Total points: 361528 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Homework Help



Books & Authors



Board Games



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You can put your settings for questions and answers on Private, but allow Fans.  Then your questions and answers will not be visible to others unless they add you as a contact.  You can choose to get an email every time someone adds you as a contact so you will know who is adding you.  Click on My Profile and then click on Edit My Info to adjust your settings.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you much...



</asker's comment>

<question>



Were these onlookers not sick?



Police have criticised a crowd of people who encouraged a suicidal teenager to jump from a shopping centre car park.



Shaun Dykes, 17, died after he fell from the site on the roof of the Westfield shopping centre in Derby on Saturday afternoon.



The teenager, a student at Heanor Gate Science College, climbed over a railing on the top level of the shopping centre's car park at 2.30pm on Saturday.



A group of onlookers gathered to watch while trained negotiators spent three hours trying to coax him down.



Witnesses said the mob taunted Shaun, who lived in the Derbyshire village of Kilburn, and shouted: "Go on then, jump."



Students from Shaun's college were nearby and heard the goading, according to his headteacher Rob Howard.



"One student told me he could not believe people place such little value on life. It's almost like they are in a television show. It's unreal," Mr Howard said.



"The sad thing is that a couple of the students, if they could have got close enough, felt that they could have made a difference. It's very traumatic."



Police condemned the onlookers and added that their presence did not help their attempts to save Shaun.



"We are disappointed that people decided to stop and watch, and some people decided to pass comments," a Derbyshire Police spokesman said.



"According to one of the police officers involved it was a small minority of people who were saying things. There's really no specific offence if people were passing comments."



The spokesman added that police did not know what had been troubling the youngster.



http://uk.news.yahoo.com/skynews/2008100...



</question>

<answer from>



rukiddin...
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 87786 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



It would! I am still in content with a friend from Scotland that I met when I was 15. (I'm as old as Barack Obama.) One of my student's father was a sailor that went into port in the Ukraine and a local teacher gave him letters from her English class to mine. I'm still in touch with her, too. It's lots of fun to get letters from other countries. I was only in contact with someone from Japan for a short time, but he showed me how to write my name in Japanese characters.



Perhaps you can try the countries at the bottom of the page in YA and ask there if some would be willing to write? Try Googling it, too. The agency I went to is no longer in business. Good luck!



</answer>

Cultures With Interesting,Beauitful Art?

<answer from>



dom .
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 1664 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



In Islam, making images of living things is generally seen as a big no-no, since you're only supposed to worship Allah, not other beings. This means that when it comes to decorating their mosques (temples), they use geometric designs instead of pictures of saints and things. Do a Google image search for "geometric Islam" and you'll come up with loads of beautiful designs: the link below is a good starting point...



Source(s):



http://www.islamonline.net/english/Scien...



</answer>

Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 197 (Level 1)

<answer>



This is easily the most intelligent question on race and/or ethnicity I have heard! Every single culture has amazingly beautiful art! There is no exception to this! From ancient tribal cave paintings to modern lineal abstract, from your local museum to the Louvre. It's all astonishing and all our wonderful commonality. ART is the ONLY thing that actually matters where the differences in race and gender are concerned, and it is all magnificent in it's own way!



</answer>

Louise

<question>



Has any one ever lead a school club or brownies etc?



I am asking because if you have lead a school club, brownies or something else I would like to know about the art activity's you did with your club so that I can gain some ideas for running a club and doing art activity's.

<answer from>



Ms. Teacher
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 665 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Halloween and Christmas (if religiously acceptable) are the best times to do crafts.  You can do some really fun things.  I have taught elementary school for a few years (grades preschool-5th).  I am still fresh and excited about doing activities and crafts!



It depends what kind of equipment you have to work with.  Laminating machines can be your best friend!  However, you can also buy the self-sticking clear laminating paper at Wal~mart or craft stores



Feel free to email me and I can give you some ideas.  I love doing things the kids have never done before (and will probably never get the chance to do).



</answer>

<answer>

Paper mache.



Plan ahead and enjoy!

<answer>



Long before black slaves were brought from Africa to America, they were brought to England. England owned Jamaica where they developed large sugar cane plantations. Blacks from Africa were shipped directly to Jamaica but bought by the country of England. All European countries had slaves before America. There were slaves in America long before America became the United States. There were not only black slaves. There were Asian and white slaves as well. African Kings sold their own people into slavery. Asians sold their people into slavery. Ireland sold their people in a different way. They offered them a way to get to America. The families that sponsored the Irish, paid their way here and then it took years for these Irish people to repay that debt to buy their freedom. So although, everyone has felt so sorry for the black slavery, you hear little about Asian and Irish  and others that were enslaved as well. The Native American were slaves to the white man. But, we never hear about this. We only hear about black slavery.



</answer>

<answer>



First you have to understand how the slave trade started.
Blacks weren't the first ones Europeans put into slavery, you know that right?? Native American were first, but many died of the hard labor and the lucky ones escaped. Then they went to Africa. Orginally on a peace mission. Talking about 'come see our king' etc etc. Then they kidnapped important chiefs. Then they chose to exchange them for commoners. Only in the 18th century did native Africans participate. And it's not like they want you to believe. Europeans try to take NO responsiblity for the slave trade... LIARS!!
It's way too much info too type here... I swear the history is LONG!
AND YES YOU DID SELL YOUR PEOPLE!! INDENTURED SERVANTS WERE HERE LONG BEFORE SLAVES!!! And what is an indentured servant you ask? A European that was sold to pay off his debt.



And even though slavery ended in 1865, racism still exists. What's worse, the segregation period from 1865 til about 1985.



The stuff white people, commoners like yourself, did to blacks to keep them down is HORRENDOUS!! Did you know ya used to go to church, and then go to a picnic to watch a black man get lynched?!?!
And, he may not have been black like we see 'black men' today. ONE DROP of African blood made you black. So if you're mothers great-grandmother was black, guess what, so ARE YOU!!  Ah ha!!



The 100 years after slavery allowed everyone is society but descendants of Africa to prosper. In fact, whites did EVERYTHING possible to prevent blacks from making a living. If a black person had a store, a white could loot and attack it, even kill the man and his family, with no reprecussions. If a black man had a car, a white person could again, kill or mutilate him, steal his car, threaten all the black people in the town, with no reprecussions. In fact, it was accepted.



This is the history they don't want you to know. But open a book. Because it's there.



And then people complain about black people in the ghettos... but who drove them there? Who would not allow them to live ANYWHERE ELSE IN THE CITY, regardless of how much money they have. You people are sick and ridiculous.



Who's responsible for slavery in the US? THE US!! a.k.a europeans, begining with the portugese and followed by many, including the infamous British.



Oh, also, READ a book. Many of the Africans who came to America before SLAVERY was skin-based became wealthy, as they were viewed as indentured servants and could by their freedom. They owned houses and land and even intermarried. Of course, America could not be the great country it is without free labor.....  and the violence they used to keep it that way.



(And, for you ignorants who believe Africans are the only reason Africans were enslaved... ask yourself... who treated them like cattle? But worse? )



And blacks are owed... but it is something that can never be repaid.  The damage is done. All we can do is make our lives better for ourselves and our community. DONT LET THE OPPRESSOR TELL YOU TO FORGET ABOUT THE OPPRESSION.



</answer>

<question>



Are young adults more interested in travel for adventure rather than cultural reasons? ?



This is part of my tourism assignment which is worth 20% and it would be great help to receive good results.



Please read the question carefully and clearly before answering as they can confuse you. If possible may you please answer clearly and in depth for all the questions as it would be great help. If there is any information that you find that it is relevant to these questions/topic please feel free to tell as it would be great to know.



Surveys: Backpackers



Select an age category:



Below 20 years of age



20 – 30 years of age



30 – 40 years of age



Gender:



Male/Female



Questions:
1.Define the meaning of adventure travel and cultural tourism?



2.Explain the differences between adventure and cultural tourism in your understanding.



3.Do you prefer adventure travel or cultural tourism more? Why?



4.Where have you travelled to?



5.Why are you travelling?



6.What are you interested in mostly?



Rate the following from one (lowest) to five (highest):



Adventure:



Cultural:



</question>



<answer from>



Jessie♫
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 2764 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Select an age category: 20 years old



Gender: Female



Questions:
1.Define the meaning of adventure travel and cultural tourism?
Adventure travel: People who go for these reasons wish to define who they are buy submissing themselves in a place far from home, meeting new people to learn about themselves and gaining independence and more knowledge of themselves.



Culrtural Tourism: People who travel for these reasons want to learn more about the world it self and open their eyes to the different cultures, perhaps to be appreciative of the things around them back home. they also seek to increase their knowledge about history and how we came to be today.



2.Explain the differences between adventure and cultural tourism in your understanding.
The differences are above



3.Do you prefer adventure travel or cultural tourism more? Why?



A bit of both, I suppose doin it for myself and self growth, but also learning about other cultures is fullfilling



4.Where have you travelled to?
Around australia, Thailand.
Am going to europe next year for 5 weeks



5.Why are you travelling?
I m traveling to learn more about myself, to meet new people, have fun!, learn more about other cultures.



6.What are you interested in mostly?
Right now im more interested in Adventure...im only 20 so i have a bit of self searching to do, but in the future i think i will lean more to the culture side of things



Rate the following from one (lowest) to five (highest):



Adventure: 10



Cultural:8



</answer>

</asker's comment>

</question from>



<question>



Do you think that "Police State" restrictions should be put on the most violent of inner cities? Why? Why not?



This would be temporary, but it would be extremely invasive as well.



"The term police state is a term for a state in which the government exercises rigid and repressive controls over the social, economic and political life of the population, especially by means of a secret police force which operates outside the boundaries normally imposed by a constitutional republic. A police state typically exhibits elements of totalitarianism and social control, and there is usually little or no distinction between the law and the exercise of political power by the executive."



This means random search and seizure, check-points, increased police presences, curfues etc.



Do you think this would help or make things worse?



http://news.yahoo.com/s/time/20080911/us...



</question>

Your overall health will decrease and your skin will be really bad, and that's just two of the downsides. I repeat: DO NOT TRY AND GAIN WEIGHT BY EATING JUNKFOOD.



Instead, use a dietry supplement used specially for gaining weight. You can buy these at pharmacies. If you're unsure, talk to a doctor, a pharmacist or a dietician. I strongly recommend seeing a doctor, for a checkup. They willl be the best judge on this.

<question>



Do you think that "Police State" restrictions should be put on the most violent of inner cities? Why? Why not?



This would be temporary, but it would be extremely invasive as well.



"The term police state is a term for a state in which the government exercises rigid and repressive controls over the social, economic and political life of the population, especially by means of a secret police force which operates outside the boundaries normally imposed by a constitutional republic. A police state typically exhibits elements of totalitarianism and social control, and there is usually little or no distinction between the law and the exercise of political power by the executive."



This means random search and seizure, check-points, increased police presences, curfues etc.



Do you think this would help or make things worse?



http://news.yahoo.com/s/time/20080911/us...



</question>

steve44m...

<answer>



It is the extreme nature of some of PETA's actions and statements that is dismissed by many in the USA.  And please don't ask questions that apply something to all Americans, or all women, or all whites, etc.



PETA has earned a reputation much like the extreme groups who blow up abortion clinics ... in their minds they think that everyone should believe as them and they do not really want to hear no for an answer.  I am sure that there are some more moderate PETA members who are not so much into forcing their beliefs on everyone else, but those members are lost in the PETA headlines when the group takes some extreme action or releases some press release (i.e. Ice cream should be made from mothers milk instead of cow's milk).  I believe that some of the extreme actions have hurt the animal rights cause because many times now people completely dismiss anything that is associated with PETA.



</answer>

<original file>1554.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk24256.txt</current file name>




<category>



Society & Culture



Cultures & Groups



</category>



<question from>



Deusa :)
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 94 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Where can I buy Brazilian products in New York City?



I recently moved to NYC from Rio and would like to find a place that sells cooking products, and other products from Brazil as well.



</question>



<answer from>



Ipanema Girl :D
Member since: 06 April 2008
Total points: 239 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The best place to get Brazilian products to prepare any Brazilian dish would be Rio Bonito Market, which is the only Brazilian supermarket in NY. There you can find a variety of cheeses, brazilian soft drinks, cooking ingredients, frozen products and even a butcher shop in the back. They also sell cooked food and household products from Brazil. You can find salgados and Brazilian juices, beer etc. A great variety.
It is located in Astoria Queens. The address is the following:



3286 47th ave near #34th ST. 718- 728 4300



There is also a smaller version of this market as a deli type located 3112 36th Ave  718- 706 7272 and in the same block you have other brazilian stores but for a greater variety go to the supermarket.



By the way they also offer travel agency service, sending boxes to Brazil and wire money.



If you are in Manhattan then you can try 46th St between 5th and 6th Ave a couple of Brazilian stores but not with too much variety.



Good Luck!!!!



</answer>

Obrigado!



</asker's comment>

<question>



Is the snailmail penpal club Science Fiction PenPal Club still going on?



I found the club back in the early 90's. It was advertised in the back of Starlog magazine. A woman named Deanne or Deanna ran it. Basically it was a snailmail penpal club for science fiction and fantasy fans. I remember she sends you a form you fill out, you check your favorite movies/shows/books etc and you can add some. Then you send it in and she sends back (I think it was for eight dollars) a penpal list that lists peoples addresses age and their interests. I know this is a long shot but I'm hoping that this will jog someone's memory

<question>



What is a mexican? Native or latin?



I see white people on mexican t.v. but every mexican i have ever seen is not of the caucasian race



</question>



<answer from>



bradwell...
Member since: 26 January 2006
Total points: 256 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Some Mexicans are very sensitive about this.  Yes, the telenovelas love to show Western-looking people who are considered attractive in Mexican culture.  It has to do with the whole issue of the Spaniards who conquered and whose descendants, for the most part, still rule Mexico. So, to answer your question, you have both.  There are very many Mexicans of strong Spanish blood, but more who have mostly indian blood.



</answer>



<answer from>



Smitty Werben Man Jenson♥
Member since: 30 March 2008
Total points: 5116 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



They are considered Latino/Hispanic. However, that is an ethnic group not a race. The actual race of most Mexicans is either Native(Metizo) or White(Spaniard) though they can be of any race really. I've seen Black,Asian, even Arab Mexicans.



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



Why are southerners, especially state employees, so passive aggressive and rude?



Transplant from NY. Has anyone else who has moved down south noticed this? The worst are secretaries, though southerners pronounce it "seckateeries". I just don't understand the lack of straight talk and the tolerance of incompetence. Any other transplants notice this strange phenomenon?



</question>



<additional details>



xxxx- I am sorry I don't understand anything you have written.



utek- that was funny. I preshiate your response. but it still doesn't answer my question. if you are a southerner, you MUST know what I am talking about. it is EVERYWHERE down here. Please tell me you know what I am talking about.



Hooyutoo- Amazing answer. I think it is one of the most coherent I have ever had on YA. Thanks.



</additional details>



<answer from>



hooyutoo...
Member since: 18 January 2008
Total points: 15143 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Didn't take you long to catch on.



There is a favorite (passive/aggressive) technique that Southerners do. They "kiddingly" insult you. This works 2 ways for them. If you don't respond and confront them, after you leave they brag to friends, "I told him to his face that he was a jerk".  But if you do actively confront them, they say, " I was just kidding... you don't have to be so nasty".



The other thing that you mentioned regarding secretaries, is that they assume that they have the same authority as the person that they work for - therefore a judge's secretary usurps the authority and demeanor of a judge.



This phenomenon was mentioned by the novelist, Taylor Caldwell when she said that, "the less authority someone has - the more they like to throw it around".



If you are living in an area away from the large metro cities you need to recognize one crucial factor. Unless you were "born and raised"  in the small town you live - you will NEVER be accepted no matter how many centuries you live there. Southerners have to have known your "mama and them" growing up - or you are persona non gratis.



The other factor is that in small town South - if you aren't a Mason - you can't even be elected dogcatcher.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Great answer.



</asker's comment>

<question from>



dawn™ Quixote
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 2308 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Why are Native Americans also called Indians?



they don't have any blood relation with the Hindu ones right?



</question>



<answer from>



Jude Adeline Starr
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 186 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because when Christopher Columbus found America he thought he was in India. He was aiming for India but landed in North America.



</answer>



<answer from>



drunken_...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 153 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



No you don't. When Columbus found America he thought he was in the Indies. Thus the name Indians.



</answer>



<answer from>



accurist...
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 3045 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Application of the term "Indian" originated with Christopher Columbus, who thought that he had arrived in the East Indies, while seeking India. This has served to imagine a kind of racial or cultural unity for the aboriginal peoples of the Americas. Once created, the unified "Indian" was codified in law, religion, and politics. The unitary idea of "Indians" was not originally shared by indigenous peoples, but many now embrace the identity.



Source(s):



(Taken directly from:- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indigenous_...



</answer>

I would love to know how Welsh people think, e.g. about themselves, about others (especially other races), about their heritage, about ways of dressing, food, health, honour, family, religion, their future etc. Wikipedia just provides general information but I need info from some Welsh folk themselves, please.

<answer>



My grandad was welsh, i know his family was against marriage outside of wales, but that's just an individuals beliefs, im sure the welsh are exactly like the british, sure they work differently and talk differently, but they don't all think the same and there not all sheep shaggers ha ha.
Wales is a beautiful place full of lush green mountains. The people are friendly for the most part. They dress the same as the folks in england they eat the same foods, although probably more lamb, there religions vary just like any place.

And i tried to refer to him as african-american cause i know that is the right terminology. But i got confused and i didn't want to sound racist again (like it happened with the japanese guy to whom i refered to as jap without knowing it was kinda racist)

Africans who live in america are refered to as African-americans
What about the ones in france? or the uk?



I know people consider racist if i say 'negro(although it is the right terminology as far as i know, like white = caucasian), black, colored, of course the N word ' and i suppose there are more words i don't know.



I got away with referring him to 'he wasn't french-french though so he spoke english weird enough, he was african-dark-like'

Now, in terms of being on the "down low." Is this a problem that mostly affects black American men? What about other types of black men (like African, Caribbean, Latin)? It seems like this is presented as an American problem. Black America does not have the level of homophobia that is present in some other black cultures. So would this be a problem for other black groups besides American?



Share your opinions, experiences.



</question>

There are other titles about this topic also.

Lisa- that's so true. It is illegal to be gay in Jamaica and has gotten many people jailed and violently killed. Do you think that in those outwardly homophobic societies, there would be a rise in down low practices since they can't be open?

<answer>



Probably the same reasons they might be racist/discriminatory towards any other group.  Most stereotypes are built on top of a grain of truth, even though that small element of truth may be historical or may not apply in any way to the person being discriminated against.  If you are not part of the in-crowd, then you become part of the out-crowd and may be misjudged or mistreated as a consequence.  It isn't fair and it isn't unique to any particular nationality or faith group.



</answer>

Member since: 06 February 2008
Total points: 931 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Islam for most of its history has been a religion of hatred and violence toward the rest of the world .



It is a world religion largely because it was spread by armed conquest.



Any people who did not convert to islam when ordered to by Mohammed and his successors were declared by mohammed  to be the enemies of Allah and mohammed and could be attacked, invaded, pillaged and enslaved at will( mohammed was allowed first pick of the captured women who were shared out as booty among his followers)



This was the true meaning of Jihad ( NOT a war of selfdefence pure aggression) which Mohammed later declared not only a right of muslims but a religious duty--- and it went on for a staggering 11 centuries.



As late as the 19th century the arabologist Doughty reported that arab fundamentalists  in S arabia wanted to unleash a fresh wave of conquest on the nonmuslim world.

Sisah bukharin



</answer>

<question>



Canadian/American Accent?



I am Canadian, but I've always thought that Candians and Americans both have the same accent. I know that there are different accents throughout the Provinces and States, but for the most part, are they the same?



</question>



<answer from>



Canadian Yummy♥Mummy
Member since: 27 February 2008
Total points: 8971 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



No,



Go down to Nfld they def. speak a different accent--some other Provinces, I can't tell the difference aside from Quebec of course.



Go down to North Carolina, Georgia, New Jersey.



We all speak a different accent, some stronger than others.



</answer>



<answer from>



Orc
Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 2595 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can't understand what you could possibly  be talking abooot !



</answer>



<answer from>



tammmy s
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 166 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have drien a truck all over the US and Canada. I can't say I remembered a distinct accent while in Canda. There were some that spoke French in Quebec, but they spoke perfect English as well. No frency accent. The only place I heard a stiking accent was Georgia. I am from Texas and a texas drawl is much different then the genteel souhtern accent of georgia. And minissota has a distinct accent but thats about it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Musica
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 22754 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



I used to think the accent in the US and Canada was the same until I went up to Victoria, British Columbia and stayed for a week. I found there are many of the locals who speak with a very distinctive British sounding accent...almost like something you'd hear on a PBS program. In fact, it's said that people in Victoria are "more English than England."  (but after going there, I'm not fully conviced that's a compliment lol)



You'll even find those with more of Scottish or Irish tinge to their voices.  However, when I ran across folks from other provinces, they don't have that very obvious British sounding accent. It's closer to American except some words are pronounced differently like "aboot" for "about"



</answer>

tammmy s

<answer>



I have drien a truck all over the US and Canada. I can't say I remembered a distinct accent while in Canda. There were some that spoke French in Quebec, but they spoke perfect English as well. <answer from>



Musica
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 22754 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



I used to think the accent in the Northern US and Canada was pretty much the same until I went up to Victoria, British Columbia and stayed there for a week. I found out that many of the locals (especially those who are upper middle class or higher) speak with a very distinctive British sounding accent...almost like something like the "Queen's English" you'd expect to hear on a PBS program. In fact, it's said that people in Victoria are "more English than England."  (but after going there, I'm not fully conviced that's a compliment lol)



You'll even find people living in Victoria who have more of a Scottish or Irish tinge to their voices. This is particularly true in the working classes.



However, when I ran across folks from other provinces, they don't have that very obvious British sounding accent like I heard in Victoria. It's closer to what American in the Northern US speak except some words are pronounced differently like "aboot" for "about"  or "oot" for "out."  and "sorey" for sorry.  If one watches the Anne Of Green Gables movies that came out in the 80s, you'll notice this difference quite a bit. Now I do have to say once I met a gal from Nova Scotia who did have the Canadian accent but with an undertone of the stereotypical New York accent in it...but she'd never been to NYC.  Weird, huh?



</answer>



<answer from>



Ali VDS This is October
Member since: 14 December 2006
Total points: 10670 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not really. Hell, Americans don't even have a uniform accent. I'm from Brooklyn and I can bet that I don't talk like someone from LA, Cleveland or Atlanta...and I don't even have a typical Brooklyn accent. So unless you find people with neutral accents, I'd say there will always be differences but some may be subtle.



</answer>

<answer>



We're all nosy by nature.



The word nosy just changes curiosity to a nasty definition. True there are some people who take it to an unbearable level. But we educate and make ourselves aware of things that we otherwise may not have known if we didn't ask a question. In life you will come across circumstances that you would have been the wiser to have asked . Sometimes it is definitely better to learn from anothers experience.



Everyone has there opinion of how far someone has to go to be classified as nosy. It comes down to respect. That comes from both sides. So don't be so quick to judge someones level of curiosity because of your level of tolerance.

Markovka

Other - Cultures & Groups

<answer>



This is a good question, but it's scary to think about. I just moved to the second largest city in Germany and have to travel back home at night, so I have to start carrying mace and not listening to my iPod so that I can be aware of my surroundings. Just being aware and alert at all times is a good way to stay safe. Oh and always scope out an escape plan.



</answer>



<answer from>



Janice Dickinsons' Shrink
Member since: 15 December 2005
Total points: 11857 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think when it comes to being out alone, I think common sense should prevail over weapons.  Especially when dating, and dealing with the opposite sex.



Mace is a good answer, but the woman would have to be on the defense since you have to be less than 10 ft away from your attacker.



Carrying a gun wouldn't hurt, but how many women want to think that the only way to feel safe is the necessity to carry a weapon?  While handgun education and training is not a bad thing, it's need should be evaluated in depth.



Self defense is always a win-win solution.  The woman gets in good physical shape and can defend herself with out the use of a weapon, and will feel more secure knowing that she has the power to keep herself safe.



Know this, not all crimes against women, that aren't Domestically related, involve guns.  A good number of adult males (not MEN) who attack women use their force as a man, or a knife, or other weapon.  Guns are usually used for robberies.



Domestic violence is a whole other issue.



</answer>

<answer from>



Society's Secret
Member since: 16 June 2008
Total points: 2099 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Other - Cultures & Groups



</answer from>



<answer>



A woman's #1 line of defense are AWARENESS and COMMON SENSE.  Be AWARE of your surroundings, and act accordingly WITH COMMON SENSE.  If your surroundings are a dark alley, don't be a freakin idiot and walk down it by yourself.



I carry a firearm, am a good shot, and am confident using it....but for many women this is not a good idea.  If you are not comfortable using a weapon when necessary, it will work against you.  Perpetrators take weapons from gals all the time, or they put them in a position where they can't get to them.  If you are not the type that can aggressively use a weapon with confidence, leave it at home.  If you are, carry it and keep it easily accessible.



Self-defense and mace are always helpful.  Being extremely LOUD is also.  But, again, common sense and awareness beat these elements hands down.  *Most* women are attacked in situations they could have easily protected themself in...lock your doors and your car doors, don't go dark places alone if you don't have to, observe who and what is nearby.  Don't look like a scared or absent-minded victim and you *likely* won't be one.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



sneak  out  of the  family  thing  and pay  the  consequences  later.  grounding  or  whatever



go to  the  boyfriends  thing  but  explain that you have  had  to  sneak  away and  you are  now  in a conflict and  see  what  he  says.

tell  him  there  was  no  way  you  were  going  to  miss, this  even  if  it  means  getting  in  lots  of  trouble  at  home.  he  might  let  you  off the  hook  but



see what  his  mood  is  like.



dont  leave  if  he  really  wants  you there because  you  promised.



your  word  is  all  you  are



and  your  parents  should  appreciate  that.

it  sounds  like  they  hit you with this at  the last  minute  and  its not really  fair to  expect  you  to  cancel long standing commitments. but  if  you  ask  them  they  are  more  than  likely  to  say  no, you  are  staying home.

if  anything



you  can  call  your  folks  from  your  boyfriends  and  tell  them  you  wont  be  able  to  make  it  home.



that at  least  puts  your  parents  in  the  bad guy  position



</answer>

</question>

Heck and i feel even more guiltly as i am sure,without meaning to,using this guy.If Tony had not hurt me then we would still be together,but he really scared me those 2 times and living in fear of someone you love is not acceptable.

<answer>



It sounds like you're still not over Tony.  (((hugs)))

If you're still in contact with him, then I guess the best thing to do would be to tell him you may be dating someone else (especially if you're concerned that others may tell him).

That being said, it's really, really hard to get over someone if you still have him in your life.  I think it may be unrealistic to expect your new boyfriend (if it turns into a relationship) and your former boyfriend to be friends.  They can be cordial to each other, but I doubt they will end up best buds.  I mean, the new boyfriend could end up being jealous of the old boyfriend, especially if you secretly still have feelings for him.

So, right now I think you should concentrate on the new prospect you have.  It could turn into something great!



Good luck!

**EDIT**  If Tony hit you twice, this changes everything.  I really think you shouldn't even be friends with him, let alone worrying about him being friends with your new guy.



</answer>

<answer>



What you are describing is a stereotype. 
I'm gay, and I do not dress like a man.
My best friend is a gay guy and he does not have any of the stereotypical mannerisms. The same is true for a couple of my other gay friends who are guys and girls.



The media enjoys spreading stereotypes like the ones you described. . .It's our duty to stop the vicious cycle of generalizing and categorizing.



For the gay people who do fit the description, who cares if they dress or act that way! That is who they are, and they are comfortable with that.



</answer>

Bret

<answer>



Once you have broadened your horizons a bit; meeting other people, you'll see that there are all kinds of things people do to be either noticed or that is the way they really feel they must express themselves.  I drive down the road all the time and see people picking their noses.  I know that they would probably not do this during a nice dinner out, but what they are doing is totally unconscious.  A lot of the mannerisms you notice are developed during that person's early years and were never corrected, did not seem important enough to be corrected or were corrected and that was ignored.  When I was little, my only friends were my older sisters.  Naturally, they became my role-models and so I wanted to be like them.  However, I grew out of that phase once I got to high-school. Please understand that it takes all kinds of folks to make up a world.  Peace to you.



</answer>
