<answer>



You are actually only asking this because of the "gay blokes" you have seen that act this specific way, there are plenty of gay men that do not act feminine at all, you just do not notice them because they are not the feminine type. As for the lesbians that dress like men? That is because they are more butch, it is the same thing, you only notice the butch lesbians because they are out of the norm. There are a lot of femme lesbians that you wouldn't even know were lesbians because they just don't look it.



As for "why". The why is because that is how they feel inside. So they dress and act on there outside the way that they feel on their insides. They don't do it "on purpose" like it is an act, that is how they are, that is how they feel, and so that is how they behaive. The same way that the class clown acts silly in class, that is because he is silly inside, or the girl that is always checking her hair and makeup, that is because that is how she is inside, that is why they act the way they act. To them, it isn't "silly talk and mannerisms", to them, it is just how they are.



</answer>

<answer>



The fact is people are different just because some people are a certain way doesn't mean all people are.  You could say why are all straight men wife beaters?  Of course they are not all wife beaters, but some are.  I could go on but the point is simple.  If people are 'effeminate' or 'butch' that doesn't mean that they are any more worthy of criticism or judgement any more than anyone else.  If you don't like 'em or they make you feel uncomfortable, don't associate with 'em!  As to why they do it, they just do, it is something or a way of life they feel comfortable with.  If that kind of thing 'floats their boat' then let it - it's their choice!  Just don't make blanket statements assuming that everyone is a certain way, because that just makes you seem stupid!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sparkles mkII
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>

I would say that the reasoning behind a gay man (I say 'a' gay man because I do not want to generalise) acting 'feminine' is because (in my opinion), to come out about their sexuality requires them to accept themselves as againsts the majority. Heterosexual men are not under this kind of pressure and are comfortable going with the majority's ideas on what is 'masculine'. Once the door has openned to accept yourself as homosexual in spite of being under disaproval, that man may also decide to open himself up to other things they would like to do that aren't usually considered acceptable for his gender. It could be that many heterosexual men may enjoy the freedom that females have in dressing in brighter colours, letting out emotion, dancing when they want etc. if they gave it the chance but are not used to going against the norm.

<answer from>



mankmunk...
Member since: 25 January 2008
Total points: 313 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are many more for German speakers



</answer>



<answer from>



Illegal Eagle
Member since: 09 September 2007
Total points: 3637 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everybody will want you to teach one of the languages. it sucks, but that's usually the way it is in a foreign country. You get typecast quickly into teaching unless you were placed by a company in that country.



Source(s):



American in Mexico. All I ever hear is "Can you teach me English?"

Look on the bright side--at least you'll never be without work.



</answer>

<question from>



Smiley
Member since: 17 July 2006
Total points: 2764 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Being older - how does it feel to get older?  Much of the notions of aging are negative - losing faculties,?



losing looks, little money etc etc plus ofcourse you are likely to have faced multiple losses like job via retirement, loss of parents, loss relatives/friends, may be lonely etc.

Is the reality really like this?



</question>



<answer from>



dunrobin...
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 16931 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



All of the things you mention plus a gradual loss of agility. More prone to illness and a gradual loss of memory.



</answer>



<answer from>



Matthew P
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 4841 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Other - Cultures & Groups



Boxing



</answer from>



<answer>



you should repost this in the senior citizens section, i will even star your question if you do.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mike K
Member since: 30 November 2007
Total points: 15401 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hello,

Well I'm 55 but do not feel it and your scenario does not have to be. Here is why:

1) LOL, like they say only mad dogs and English men go out in the noon day sun and with that philosophy as well as constant facial cream and oil treatments from my wife, wrinkles have not appeared yet.



2) I kept physically active, not fanatically mind you but well enough to work in the garden, ride bikes load and unload trucks etc so I am not lying around like an invalid.

3) We baby boomer types do not have that big generation gap that we did with our parents "Great Generation" so we have kept up with all the changes and have been far more accepting with regards to society.

4) There is no need to suffer seeing loved ones go if you include friends over a wide span of years. I am involved in many community activities and have friends from 20 - 85 years old.

5) My type of work is not physical so I can do it until 75, assuming I have no crippling illness. Even if your nest egg is perfect, it is foolish to lie around or go to bingo or golf courses all day. Take courses from woodworking to foreign languages and your mind should stay sharp barring biochemical problems.



So all in all you are the Captain of your own ship and can make what you want out of old age.

By the way, Iwas amazed at how fast the years flew between 25 and 50... they seemed to go 5x faster than my first 25 years; can't say I wasn't warned and I'll pass this on to you!

Cheers,

Michael Kelly



</answer>

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It would be absurd to or not to welcome somebody merely on account of their race.  There are other facts to be taken into account when making such a decision.

I am from the UK, although currently living in Korea.

In 2002, I spent three months in China.  I took away from that trip that generally Chinese people are very welcoming, giving and friendly.

Despite the language barrier, the Chinese would try to help you in any way that they could.

Towards the end of the trip, though, we tried to avoid asking for directions as it would be embarrassing.

The Chinese, working as a chain of total strangers, would get you escorted to your destination.  Here is an example using London place names:  You would be at Paddington Station and ask Person A how to get to the National Gallery.  Person A would find someone (Person B) taking the Bakerloo Line Southbound, tell them where you wish to go and give you to Person B.  Person B would find someone (Person C) getting off at Charing Cross, tell them where you wanted to go and give you to Person C.  Person D would escort you outside the station and find somebody (Person E) going past the National Gallery and give you to them.

I can't imagine that a chain of strangers in the UK would help a foreigner in the UK - but the Chinese often did that in China without thinking twice about it!

I very much welcome visitors to the UK - we have a fantastic country which I love to show off!  Please welcome all visitors to the UK warmly!

Nick
:)



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>

Calligraphy? Beautiful.
Philosophy? Fascinating.
People? Sure thing!

:))



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AkbJLO7Z.0qUCmOSYEvx.2AGBgx59b9.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk35796.txt</current file name>



<category>



Society & Culture



Cultures & Groups



</category>



<question from>



Suzie s
Member since: 13 November 2007
Total points: 4089 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Does anyone remember Chic Murray?



Chic Murray, the famous Scottish actor and comedian, is the subject of this page, which has been dedicated to him. Scottish humour is appreciated throughout the World but Chic's humour is both unique and incredibly funny. It's very difficult to do it justice in print but here goes anyway ...
 Visiting London, Chic was asked by a stranger, "Do you know the Battersea dog's home?". He replied, "I didn't even know it was away."
 When staying at a Rothesay hotel, there were the usual toast and marmalade (in little round pots) on the breakfast table in the morning. When the landlady came into the room, Chic lifted a tiny pot of honey and said "I see you keep a bee!"
 It's a small world, but I wouldn't want to have to paint it.



My mother was so house proud that when my father got up to sleepwalk she had the bed made by the time he got back.



My father was from Aberdeen, and a more generous man you couldn't wish to meet. I have a gold watch that belonged to him. He sold it to me on his deathbed. I wrote him a cheque for it, post dated of course.



I made a stupid mistake last week. Come to think of it, did you ever hear of someone making a clever mistake?



So I gave him a wave. Actually, it was more of a half wave, because I only half know him.



What use is happiness? It can't buy you money.



I met this cowboy with a brown paper hat, paper waistcoat and paper trousers. He was wanted for rustling.



If something's neither here nor there, where the hell is it?



My father was a simple man. My mother was a simple woman. You see the result standing in front of you, a simpleton.



I had a tragic childhood. My parents never understood me. They were Japanese.



I won't say I was slow developer, but our teacher was quite pleased to have someone her own age in the class to talk to.



If it weren't for marriage, husband and wives would have to fight with strangers.



After I told my wife that black underwear turned me on, she didn't wash my Y-fronts for a month.



Kippers- fish that like a lot of sleep.



</question>



<answer from>



Havas nana
Member since: 08 September 2007
Total points: 30918 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



I never heard of him , but that is some funny material.



</answer>



<answer from>



w b
Member since: 30 July 2007
Total points: 2921 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



very funny.hehe

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Mur...



</answer>

CARAMAC

Total points: 5724 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes I remember him... but you sound as if you'd make a good comedian as well, ever thought of taking it further and maybe getting some of your own material.

It's sad when you think of just how many 'funny men' and women we've lost or they just don't appear anymore.



Morecombe and Wise was my favourite, I loved Dave Allan, Ruby Wax is great, and Billy Connolly, there's so many really great comedians past and present.

Caramac x



</answer>

<answer from>



lilberni

XI XXV
Member since: 17 June 2008

<answer>



Walk outside of your room... Go up to your mom and ask what time dinner will be ready.



Be ready to catch her as she faints.



Good luck!



-----

In all seriousness though, just sit your folks down privately and politely tell them. Anything of this gravity (like sexuality, gender identity, and "dress roles"?) will take a little time to get used to. Plus it's better that it comes from your mouth rather than them finding out from some nosy, gossiping neighbor.



</answer>

<answer>



Consult the closest of your two parents or even if you have a sister (or close female cousin) your age about your cross dressing. I would not go to breakfast dressed that way. I would talk to them seriouisly and try and explain why you want to do this. They will probably want to know when it first started or maybe they have suspected all along, not sure. You should do some research on your part to try and understand your situation and the consequences better. Does your school have programs that might help you or any places in town that provide information for CD or LGBT community members?

If you have two loving parents they will accept you for the way you are. Depending on your age they might accept your "cross dressing" only in private, or do you want to make wear women's clothes all the time? Maybe a close friend or girlfriend would be someone you could talk to about this before you let them know.

Are you transgendered or is this just a cross dressing curiousity. Some web sites and links might be helpful. Good luck.

http://www.critpath.org/pflag-talk/tgKID...
http://womensrights.suite101.com/article...

can anyone in scotland who has recieved there gcse results a few days ago and did english gcse foundation paper what grade their got

</answer from>



<answer>



As a resident in Scotland, you need to be aware that Scottish students don't follow the GCSE course. They do Intermediate 1 or 2 and Standard Grades.

<answer from>



Sωєєt ∂єℓυѕιση♥ [AM]
Member since: 02 July 2008
Total points: 7032 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Religion & Spirituality



Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgendered



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds like you are suffering from anorexia, or at least that's the way you are headed.
That is a very, very dangerous disease. It's a mindset that may eventually end up killing you, if you do not watch out.

What I think you should do?
I think you should talk to someone about it. A psychiatrist would probably be the best solution. Or a teacher you trust, perhaps. I know that you probably do not think there is anything wrong with you whatsoever.. But please, listen to me! I have friends who have gone through the very same thing. One of them almost died from it! Do you want to end up like her? Act now, before it is too late.

..I wish you nothing but the best!
Good luck.

PS: If you want to lose weight, go on a diet. Talk to a doctor. Do NOT try to starve yourself under any circumstances.



</answer>

<answer>



It is actually ok not to eat for a few days and fast every now and then. Not eating can actually be good if used appropriately and for the right reasons.  Juice and water fasts can purge the body of toxins, clear the skin, make your think more clearly, and increase your health.  Fasting can make you feel sick because your body is starting to feel the toxins being purged from your body rapidly. If you do it too long and too often however, it can be extremely dangerous.

You need to understand the difference between thin and anorexic. Thin is losing fat and toxins from the body.

You can stay thin by excercizing, eating a diet of fruits, grains, and veggis and by drinking pleanty of water. Get a juicer and a blender and make drinks, juices, and smoothies. Stay away from processed foods, mean such as hamburger which is full of fat and grease, twinkies, fried chicken and other similar foods.

If you eat a natural vegitarian diet, excersize regularly, drink pleanty of water, go to bed at a reasonable hour and get pleanty of sleep.  You can eat unlimited veggies because they are processed quickly through your body and give your body the nutrition it needs. You can have a few whole wheat pieces of toast a day with cinimon and olive oil. You can have some fruit and oatmeal for break fast as oatmeal will help rid your body of colestoral. DO NOT GO ON THE  ATKEN'S DIET, IT CAUSES PERMANENT DAMAGE TO THE BODY. The Atkins diet has you eat fatty food with little nutrition. With the atkinds diet, you lose water weight, but not very much fat.

If you do these things, you will have the body of a movie star. Many movie stars eat a vegitarian diet or more vegitables than the normal person.  Being a vegitarian is the key to losing weight. I am thin. I knew a guy who was thin and when he got of a vegitarian diet, he got fat again.

Also, DO NOT drink diet sodas. Nutrasweet causes obesity and weight gain. If you want soda, get charged water and add juice or pick up some natural soda's at your local health food store.



</answer>

<answer>



Um. I think it would take you about two weeks of starving yourself to get the results you want. In two days you might lose a few pounds but in the long run starving yourself is counter productive because right after you have finished starving your self and you eat your first meal, your body will make a mad rush to store a great deal of body fat to prepare you for another starving period. You will end up gaining more weight than you lost. This approach will then lead you to an eating disorder and poor health. Have you seen the pictures of starving people in africa? They have bloated bellies. Starvation does not work. Only a combination of diet and exercise will help you to sculpt your body. That is another thing. Do you want to lose weight or change your figure? Starving your self will not make you more shapely. I suggest, that if you are serious about changing your body, you go see a nutritionist and an physical trainer, or whatever they are called. If you keep with a personally designed program, you should feel some results in about a month and you should see some results in two to three months. All good things come with time, and no, there is no quick fix for body sculpting. If you are hell bent on ignoring the truth because you do not like it, you may try lipozine or similar drugs to help you lose weight, maybe then you will listen to reason.



</answer>

If you starve yourself the fat will eat itself, and you won't lose any weight. Try this:
Breakfast: 1 Mini Wheat Bagel with butter 7am
Snack: 1 piece of Fruit or 1 string cheese 10am
Lunch: Salad ( As much as you want with no meat) Any dressing 12pm
Snack: 1 piece of Fruit or 1 string cheese 3pm
Dinner: What ever you want just be reasonable in portion size 6 or 7pm
Snack: 1 cup of non butter popcorn 8:30
Good Night

Try this it may work for you. I know it worked for me. In 9 months time I went from 300lbs. to 224lbs. I'm still going strong, and I feel great. Good Luck, and don't starve yourself. Time to let go of the candy bars; cake; Ice cream, and you will be fine.

<answer>



I went through this already. It worked! Except I was REALLY weak, sick, and moody all the time.

When you lose weight by not eating you will lose weight but when you start eating you will GAIN weight faster. Losing weight this way fools your body to conserve energy so when you DO eat your body won't burn as many calories so your metabolism will slow down.



( I'm a major health freak so listen to me please. I don't want you to go what I went through. )

If you really want to be skinny REALLY bad then I suggest you go on a balanced diet and WORK OUT at least 30 minutes everyday. Anything that involves physical activity and sweating.

Here's your diet plan. If you eat whole wheat, fresh fruit, vegetables, nuts, seeds, lean meats, and drink nothing but water then you will lose weight. Sodas and fruit juices have a lot of sugar. Stay away from sugar! More healthy foods please. Also eating more of small portioned food will make you lose faster because your metabolism will always be working.

Breakfast:
Whole Wheat Toast - 2 slices
2 cups of Cottage Cheese.
Fresh fruit - Bananas  / strawberries/ blueberries/ apples/ or watermelon. & water

If you don't like cottage cheese then have EGG WHITES. no yolk with some cheese.

Lunch: A sandwich with whole wheat bread, NO MAYO, a lot of vegetables, cheese, and chicken breast.

A light Dinner: A ceasar chicken salad with any kind of dressing with vinegar. No heavy dressings like ranch or thousand island.



If you don't have time to make a breakfast then grab a protein shake with some veggies & snack and go.

The reason why I wrote so much is because I can't stand another person starving themselves to lose weight because it doesn't work forever & you will damage your body.

I lost 30 lbs in 3 months. Have fun and eat healthy.



Source(s):



ME!



</answer>

<question>



Who has been to N/A meetings and what are they like?



</question>



<additional details>



THANK YOU Peter G:I don't think I will get up and speak first time, til I get used to it.



</additional details>



<answer from>



peter g
Member since: 22 June 2007
Total points: 6146 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've been to N/A meetings and they really helped me. They reminded me that i'm not alone and there ARE people who understand what life is like on drugs and who are inspirational in that they too struggle with life without drugs.

In an N/A meeting people get up and just speak about whatever the subject is for the day. Subjects might be things such as 'relationships' or 'hope'.

You dont have to speak if you dont want to. In fact its a good idea first time you go to approach the leader and let them know who you are and tell them that you'd prefer not to speak. You speak when you are good and ready.

Introduce yourself to people and just be yourself. Be prepared to give a couple dollars in donation to help the group do things like rent out the meeting space and such. Though you dont have to donate if you dont want to.

I think you'll find that you'll be able to relate to a lot of people there and they'll be able to relate to you.

I wish you luck and serenity.



</answer>



<answer from>



deepred
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 3096 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've been to many, and you will find them supportive, open and caring, and also very welcoming.
I wish you well with your recovery



</answer>

<question>



Why do half-caste (mixed race) people look like North Africans?



I have noticed that multiracial people tend to resemble the Arabs of North Africa, (Tunisians, Morroccans, Libyans, Algerians etc).



Why is this? Bearing in mind that from what I've read, the blacks of sub-saharan Africa didn't mix with them.

<additional details>



Do you people even read the question, and the details?



North Africans are Arabs. There has been very little mixing with black Africans, because there was a huge desert, which prevented Blacks from being there, until recently when cars and planes were introduced.

<answer>



Since your relationship with him is over (even if you still love him), there's nothing you can do if he falls for someone else (even if it's your best friend).



And if she really is your best friend, then you should be happy for her.  I guess, this guy is cool because you still love him.  But you have to face the reality that it was not meant to be.  Because if it is, then why are you not together anymore?

You've set him free.  If he comes back to you one day, then maybe that's the right time for you guys to be together again.  But for now, it's him and your best friend.

Hurts, yeah, but you need to learn to accept it.



</answer>

<question from>



waggy
Member since: 10 April 2006

</question from>



<question>



Is 'coming out' destructive self indulgence or a necessity



</question>



<answer from>



rainbow
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 761 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



it could be either and or all!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Philip H ™
Member since: 31 January 2008
Total points: 3506 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most of the time its self indulgent, most of the time people go "no sh*t shirlock, we knew that years ago"



</answer>



<answer from>



Kayla99
Member since: 22 April 2008
Total points: 324 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is a personal necessity.

I think sometimes people become so focused on the idea of it's social unacceptability, or it's "abnormality" that they begin to become more private and self-concerned because society just doesn't seem to like, accept, or understand them just the way they are.

Also, mentally, I think if someone has been hiding that, as I said before, is socially unacceptable, and is very life changing because they have never expressed how they have been feeling for so long, when they let it out, it seems like it is what your life has to revolve around.

No I don't think it is destructive self indulgence, but I think to alot of people who don't understand the process or feelings of coming to terms with sexuality, sexual orientation, gender identity, etc, it can off as very selfish and destructive to relationships and people around them.



</answer>



<answer from>



Declan L
Member since: 06 October 2007
Total points: 282 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Coming out isn't nessescary but it's makes your life a lot lot easier



</answer>



<answer from>



PabloG
Member since: 01 January 2008
Total points: 1792 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



By people feeling that they HAVE to "come out" - they are just confirming that there is something about themselves that people have to know, that there is something so wildly different about them than the rest of the population that they need to proclaim it to everyone.



When someone is straight they do not ever feel the need to go around telling people about it. Why do gay people then feel they have to, or that it is expected to announce their feelings to the world? It is especially stupid when people "come out" and make a big announcement to the world, when they are not even in a relationship! I mean, why tell people who you are looking at? Straight people dont!



It's the kind of talk about needing to "come out" blah blah blah that convince 14 year olds who maybe are confused feel that they MUST tell all and sundry that they are gay, when who cares what anyone is or is going to be when that person is a child?! It's taking away the fact that straight feeling teens may not always be that way and also gay feeling teens may also change their minds... It's making people choose a ridiculous unnecesary label!



Nobody should ever need to come out, unless it's to someone they are about to embark in a sexual relationship with!



</answer>

<question from>



daly_tho...

<question>



Is part of being vegan not wearing animal furs and ect.?



</question>



<answer from>



Jen A.
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 250 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm pretty sure it is, not necessarily because they come out and say it, but I'm pretty sure if you said you were vegan and then put on a leather jacket, i'd be pretty confused.

The vegan groups and animal cruelty groups tend to go hand in hand.



</answer>



<answer from>



Abby Normal
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 1397 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes.
Being vegan you eat and wear NO animal products.
Some everyday animal products people don't usually think about that aren't vegan: honey, yeast (breads), Worcestershire sauce (anchovies in ingredients) and some sugars are processed with bone meal.



</answer>

<question>



Do you sometimes worry that you may look better in pictures than in person?



Does anyone take a bunch of pictures and post the ones that look the best even if they don't really look like the real you? Does that bring up pressure when you're going to meet someone in person for the first time?

I believe I look better in my pictures and its a constant struggle to try and live up to how I look in them. The thing is, I'm not photogenic at all, the pictures of myself that I usually post on Myspace or something are the best ones of the bunch. If I were to post the other ones then I would definitely look better in person but I don't want to post pictures in which I feel like I look hideous on. But I would much rather prefer that people find me better looking in person than in pics. I know people always compare you to your pics when they finally see you in person.



</question>



<additional details>



Yes, I posted it on the LGBT category cuz I'm a lesbian myself and it makes me feel at home! I enjoy my peoples answers =)



</additional details>



<answer from>



chyah
Member since: 20 July 2008
Total points: 399 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i think everyone does that. take a bunch of pics and choose the best to put up on myspace. my problem is the opposite of yours, i'm not photogenic, and i look better in person. you shouldn't have to feel like you need to live up to your pictures, other peoples' expectations of what you look like. a lot of people look a little different from their pics. just do you, if they have a problem with it, they shouldn't look:)

and i noticed that this question is in the lesbian gay bisexual and transgendered section. that's funny.



Source(s):



life.



</answer>



<answer from>



Suprem...
Member since: 15 August 2007
Total points: 2861 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honey....a LOT of people do the SAME thing you do.



Everyone takes at least a few bad pictures.  You are being WAY too hard on yourself.

Cameras aren't completely accurate (actually far from it, unless it's a REALLY expensive camera).  They represent you in 2D.  What people see you as is 3D, with all of your beautiful features accentuated.  Because cameras don't normally reflect your true dimensions, many times pictures that you take will not look like who you really are and what everyone else sees in you.



As for the mirror, well that can be misleading as well.  Think, you see yourself EVERY DAY.  You're so used to yourself that even when you'll look absolutely gorgeous, you will find something bad to say about yourself.  Why?  Because you're not satisfied.  You have a preconceived notion in your mind that you don't look good, so you see what you expect to see.  However, that really isn't how others see you.



I can assure you that absolutely EVERYONE goes through this.  It's nothing to worry about, honey! =)



Honestly, I hate taking pictures unless they're with a really good camera (like a DSLR or something).  Truthfully, people VERY often compliment me on how wonderful I look, but when I take a picture with a crappy camera I just want to hide!  Haha



It's a phase.  It'll pass!  =)  You're not alone in this! &lt;3



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



Qyllix
Member since: 06 November 2006
Total points: 4979 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Democratic party has turned "political correctness" into its own form of censorship.  If you don't agree with the message they are currently espousing then you must be saying something wrong.  What is wrong with open dialog, and not getting upset when people have different views?  Isn't that what America was founded to protect?



</answer>



<answer from>



kay
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 1026 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not, you have the right to any opinion, but people also have the right to disagree with you.



</answer>



<answer from>



waggy
Member since: 10 April 2006
Total points: 13567 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Personally I believe in freedom of speech and the right to have differences of opinions.  In fact I like nothing more than a good debate.  What I don't like and I think any rational person wouldn't either.  Is hard headed ignorance.  That is refusing point blank to see that you are in the wrong and need to reform the way you may view something.

To be more specific to your question.  I'm not quite sure what you mean by 'critical of homosexuality'  If you mean critical of someone who happens to be homosexual - then I would ask does your criticism have anything directly to do with their homosexuality?  If so that is where there may be a problem as homosexuality in itself isn't really that controversial it is about what 'floats your boat' not really contravening any laws of nature.  However some people do use homosexuality as a means of excusing bad behaviour eg promiscuity, extreme opinions or actions and so - that I don't agree with and I think would be a valid means of criticising on the grounds of being homsexuality.

My point is just criticising someone for being homosexual isn't really a valid or logical argument.  Criticising a person because of the way they choose to use their sexuality might be.  As to why people can appear overly sensitive.  it could be due to their own ignorance, lack of education, misunderstanding your motives or fear of actually being proved wrong!



</answer>



<answer from>



T
Member since: 14 December 2007
Total points: 292 (Level 2)



</answer from>

Cheers



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Senior Citizens - My Dad says that this world does not feel like his world any more - do you share his ?



sentiment and in what ways?  An answerer in another Q put how he was brought up in a world where you were raised to face the world head on at age 16 and so I wondered in what other respects things feel alien/different?



</question>

Buddha

</answer from>



<answer>



In so many ways, it would take all night to answer but I will tell you a few of them.  People were brought up to take responsibility for their actions.  There was less crime, whatever statistics tell us.  We were a united nation and neighbours knew each other and helped each other.  There was no multi-culturalism, which I personally don't like.  Children were more polite and obedient and there was very little traffic on the roads.



Source(s):



Being 63



</answer>

The best of life is the past and the present is not the way things should be. Just because it's 2008 does not mean what was once right is now wrong and what was once wrong is now right. But look around you!!! People do what they want, what feels good. Having a good time seems to take top priority and as far as money, people worship it and no one thinks they have enough.

<answer from>



Allison in Wonderland
Member since: 10 August 2008
Total points: 241 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When I was young, we were told be in when the street lights come on.  We were brought up more strict.  We got a crack in the behind when we were bad, (mouthy, late, or not polite).  I didn't like it, but I grew up with more respect for my elders.  I remember a girl friend making fun of an older woman (we were about 12), she was hunched over.  I was hurt for this woman and I swore from that day on, I would never hurt an older person.  Many years passed I lost my job after 23 years, I was lost.  So I did volunteer work for a Senior home with my Collie, she looked like Lassie.  It was one of the most rewarding things I'd ever done.  Helping others and being kind is such a reward and helping thing for you and the person(s) you are assisting.  I all the bad good be reversed to good, what a wonderful world this would be.  Love, be kind, and you will be rewarded 10 fold.  I continue to help others when I can. Those days I miss, respect yourself too!  Hope this helped.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



There was much less crime and people took responsibility for their actions. There was more morality and less looking for instant gratification. Hard work was rewarded by employers who provided secure jobs. There were less electronic gadgets and people werent being replaced by machines. There was less interaction between races but more respect for others overall. We taught our children values and discipline and to follow the golden rule.



</answer>

<answer from>



Heather
Member since: 13 November 2007
Total points: 232 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Has your dad kept up with the world today or is there some time period in which he seems to prefer?  I read 20 years ago we were inundated each day with more information than most people living in the 17th century received during their lifetime.  Don't quote me on the century, but you get the idea.  What I see about today's world is the lack of any time to reflect.  There is no sense in learning about something in depth because it will all be different tomorrow, so why bother.  There is a shallowness in today's thinking which is deeply disturbing.  Everything is condensed to a sound bite (or is it byte?).  People are impatient, utterly rude and self centered today.  Diversity has brought unintended consequences.



My grandkids think I'm off because I like old things, keep my old clothes, stay in my old house.  It's sort of funny really, because I'm connected to the internet all the time.  My 7 year old granddaughter learned about landlines at my house and was absolutely in awe that you could talk to somebody from the kitchen and the bedroom at the same time.  She also accused me of being rude because I don't answer telephone calls during meals.  She has yet to learn telephone callers don't have eyes through the phone.

There comes a point where you sometimes want to say enough, I'd just like to sit in the same spot and rest here a while.  And that can be something our society should start doing.



Source(s):



lots of miles under my feet



</answer>



<answer from>



bluelady...
Member since: 16 April 2008
Total points: 1788 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am in my fifties and the world today is indeed my world. I try not to whallow in the past to which alot of seniors seem to do. I try to keep up with current events and I try to move with the evolution of technology. If you are filled with the joy of life the world doesnt seem foreign. Your father sounds like he had a hard life a life where he was not encouraged to find his inner self but to be self sustaining and that is where he found himself. He needs a passion a hobby and then our world today will be his world and wont seem so alien to him.



Source(s):



Our world has improved. Child molestation is no long pushed under the rug neither is child beatings. People do not beat their wives and feel they have a right to do so. Equal opportunity for women and the injustice towards racism and intolerance is exposed. Children are living a healthier life due to vaccine and so all in all things have improved. Yes crime is on the rise but then again think of lynchings and murder and how many innocent black and other minorities were falsely accused. There is help for the alcoholics and recognition of it being a disease. Help for leukemia so children often recover. Cancers so many of them today are treatable. I will never look back in nostalgia, I look ahead in advancement thank you very much.



</answer>

Liz
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 517 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm pretty sure it would be Saudi Arabia. It's where the most fundamental muslims are. They have capital and corporal punishment for homosexuality and even promoting it is a crime punishable by imprisonment. Their media is heavily censored and there is basically no homosexuality represented in the media. Whatever LGBT community there is in Saudi Arabia is very underground and secretive.
Other countries, especially in the middle east and Africa still recognise homosexuality as a criminal offense and, in many places, mostly muslim dominated (i'm not stereotyping, i'm sorry, it's just a fact), homosexuality is referred to as sodomy and is punishable by death. I think Saudi Arabia is so bad because of how fundamentalist they are.



</answer>

<answer>



So Suzie:  I got this new replacement credit card from Bof A yesterday, only the only company name on it was American Express.  I called the office and got a sweetie who explained it all to me but I told him I didn't want an AmEx card.  I asked what was my current BofA APR and he said 9.99, I said cancel the card.  Answer: why?  cause I got a much better card I've been using at 6.9. He says, Who was that?  I said, RBS.  He said who is RBS?
I said (with much flourish, like I owned the company), well, that's the Royal Bank of Scotland....do you think they will go broke?  He was dumfounded.



</answer>

I've explained to them what different orientations their are and how some people are prejudice against it. It seems today is not my day. How can i cheer her up and also how can i approach Jamie's parents in a civil manner?

P.S Telling me i shouldn't have children and that i am certainly messing up their life by being gay is not helpful, its small minded, i can't make my children gay, just like straight people can't make their children straight. At the end of the day all i can teach my child is love is love no matter colour, creed or sex.



</question>



<additional details>



i will be going into see her teacher when i pick up the other two that attend this school, both me and my partners will be there for them, although i will be the only one going into the meeting. So in the mean time, i made her her favourite snack and let her play with her paint set in the dining room. Needless to say we will be having a family meeting tonight in regards to bullying and how its important to respect how other people choose to live their lives and their opinions.



</additional details>

As for your daughter, she has probably realised she has two mums instead of a dad and a mum, hell most black people only have a mum, so its all swings and roundabouts anyway, just explain people love who they love, and she is entitled to love anybody as well.

<answer>



First of all let's not lose sight of the fact that we have an innocent and beautiful 4 year old child that is being hurt. With that said, get up off your backside, contact your child's school and establish an appointment. Also schedule one with "child protective services". Go to the meetings and present your case firmly showing you will not back down. Showing up in person let's them know you are very serious about your complaint and it sends this very psychological message.



Inform them there is no options, the harassment must stop immediately or legal action will be taken. You have an inborn instinct to protect your daughter and being a human you will also be setting an example to her that wrongs can be righted.



Tell your daughter also that the boy (offender) is wrong, and he nor his parents have the authority or right to determine who is or who is not going to hell. Tell her it is simply silly for them  to think otherwise.

Also, let her know there are people on earth who aren't very bright and she has simply met one of them. Teach her also not to hate, but to pitty and have compassion on such people because they will lead cold and miserable lives.

Now, get up, walk over to the phone and set this defense of your daughter in motion....



Hope this has helped...



Source(s):

<answer>



I am sorry to hear of your daughters upset, children can say the harshest things, it is likely that Jamie is being influenced by what others around them are saying, i.e. their parents. I would not advice approaching their parents directly but instead opt for an approach were your daughters teachers and Jamie's parents are present. that way with a third person as an intermediary such as a teacher there is less likely to be abused hurled at one another and a constructive conversation can occur to help in your daughters best interests.



</answer>

<question>



Relationship question.?



So, Im 14, and i know im kinda young to be asking these questions, but I really don't feel like going to my mom and asking her!

So, me and my boy friend have been dating for a week and two days now, and im quit confused on how he wants to take things.

Hes so confusing, I really have no clue what to do.

For example, I was talking to him the other day, and he was acting quit weird. So i was trying to get whatever was wrong with him out, so finley he said that our relationship was moving too fast, and i totally agree. We've been dating for a week now, and I love you has already been said. He said it even be-for we started dating, so i said it back, and truly i know im only 14 but iv never felt like this, he makes me feel amazing, like im the only person in the world he cares about, so i said it back.

So when i asked him how we where taking things to fast, he said it was about sex, and love.

We've talked about sex, we talk about every day.
Once again i know im too young to do these things.
And if i do have sex with him, i should wait, so it can really mean something.

So i agree about how we need to slow things down.

BUT, this is where im confused.
After saying that, when he had to go he said " I love you Amber. "
He just got done telling me, we should say this till we where farther in our relationship.

Then, that next day, he was saying he couldent wait till i was in his bed, and how he wanted to " bone " me.

And how this weekend, we where going to do things.

So then that where i come in, and freek out on him for sending me mixed emotions.



What should i do?
I really do have strong feelings for him, iv never felt like this about ANYONE!

I think i love him.
I think i want to have sex with him?

What should i do.
Should i keep things going slow, or should i jump to things?



</question>

<answer>



You want to confront him about matters of personal choice of how he spends his leisure time?  That's ridiculous.

You spend your leisure time how you like and he spends his leisure time how he likes.  From the sounds of it, there are no problems with his work life.  There is nothing you have any right confronting him about.

If you feel uncomfortable spending six months with him, ask your manager to reconsider the assignment.  If he feels that there are no changes to make and you still don't want to go away with him, ask for your P45 and look for another job.

You cannot make innocent other people (even if they are part of a minority group) a scapegoat for your own insecurity.  Once you are confident with yourself and accepting with yourself, you will not feel so jealous of people who are secure with themselves.

Nick
:)



</answer>

Going away with him for six months should not be a problem - you donothave to make him your friend.



</answer>

I doubt that they are coming on to him. parents tend to be very blind when it comes to these things. they would have to go down the checklist of gay things: horribly skinny, has the accent, you know the stereotypes (not that i ever thought that being a vegetarian was ever one...) but that doesn't mean that they would realize it in the end.

What can you tell him to comfort him? not much other than that you love him and will be there for him (that is if you are at the L word stage yet). <question>



Do they B.N.P hate me beacause iam black ?



i have nothing against the B.N.P infact iam thinking off voting for them.but is it a contidiction,like a jew voting for the nazi party? (IAM NOT COMPARING BNP TO THE NAZI PARTY)

so  i need someone to help me answer this quistion



so iam black british,and so is my mum,my mums boyfreind is white angilo saxon English and his family go on thousands of years back,his grandfather was a very succesful buisness man owning a manopoly of pubs and his dad and insurance broker and now he is a buisnesman so if me and my mum were kicked out it would not be a problem beacuse my mums partner could so easily buy us a house in america or were our cousins are in germany &lt;-----worst possible situation i know, but Do they B.N.P hate me beacause iam black ?



</question>



<answer from>



Mr Sceptic
Member since: 03 September 2007
Total points: 12276 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



I'm not sure that individual members of the BNP hate you as a black individual.

They just don't think that you shoud be living in this country, and they would argue against the term 'black British'. The BNP believe it is impossible to be both. They would seek to remove you and your Mum from our land.

They would also discourage your Mum's boyfriend from having anything to do with your family - they disapprove of inter-racial relationships.



Ten years ago, BNP leader Nick Griffin said:

Without the White race nothing matters [other right-wing parties] believe that the answer to the race question is integration and a futile attempt to create "Black Britons", while we affirm that non-Whites have no place here at all and will not rest until every last one has left our land."



BNP supporters claim he has changed his mind. You have to decide if a man who makes such a public statement can ever be trusted.



s



</answer>

badkitty...
Member since: 14 March 2006
Total points: 34380 (Level 7)

<answer>



8 years ago today I was just starting to get my life back together after going through one of the worst depressions of my life.  After bullying myself through the loss of my son by trying to work myself to death for a year, I basically spent the following 6 months having a long slow nervous breakdown - and the f*cked up part was that I STILL refused to acknowledge that I was having any sort of problem.  In addition, several of the people I worked with decided that I was "weak" and that they were going to mess with me (wrong!).



After not sleeping for AT ALL for 6 months, not eating, working 12-hour days, taking excessive abuse at work, and getting involved with the world's biggest @sshole, I finally realized that I had completely emptied myself out and had absolutely NOTHING left.  8 years ago today-ish, I found a new job (literally across the hall from my old job, but for $12K more per year), pimp-smacked the @sshole out of my life, and started going to therapy.



I ended up working for a group of people that I truly loved, and I also was able to laugh my @ss off when my old team lost their contract a few months later (because I am evil).  That one job transfer gave me the amazing opportunty to work where I am now (I can't even begin to explain).  The world's biggest @sshole is still among my general group of aquaintences and all of his ex's seek me out when plotting his demise (because DC is a small town and karma is a b*tch).



Finally, while you can never get over losing a child, you can grow past it and let yourself heal, and although it has taken me years to realize how much damage I was doing to myself by internalizing everything and trying to be "tough", I think I have finally gotten to a place where I can finally allow myself to breathe - whereas looking back 8 years ago I didn't realize that I wasn't breathing at all.



</answer>

<question>



How do you know if you are bisexual?



In highschool I found myself having a crush on one of the girls I played volleyball with.  At the time I was not comfortable with it and it freaked me out a little.  I felt like the only reason I had a crush on her was because she was an open bisexual and therefore I wanted her to like me.  I am the type of girl who can have a crush on almost anyone.  I want every guy to like me, and if they're into it, every girl too.



Now in college I find myself around this same girl again, and the feelings are returning.  I am more open to it now, five years later.  But I am starting to question my sexuality. Now I look at girls and find them attractive. None of my close friends, I could never see them that way, but like strangers??? Any ideas?
Am i attracted to this girl because I want her to like me? or
Am i bisexual? advice thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Sexual Harassment Panda
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 421 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



OUT NOW!
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 69 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index;...



</answer>



<answer from>



ren p
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 260 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you dont want to be, you can come over to my place!



</answer>



<answer from>



Blood Fire
Member since: 19 May 2008
Total points: 172 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bisexuals are people who are attracted to both men and women. Bisexuals sometimes get a bad rap. There are many myths and misconceptions about bisexual women. This article will attempt to dispel some of the myths about bisexual women.



1. Myth: Bisexual Women are Really Straight
Fact: Bisexual women are attracted to both men and women. Some bisexual women are more attracted to women. Others are more attracted to men. Some are equally attracted to both men and women. Where ever they fall in the spectrum, a bisexual woman is someone who enjoys intimacy with both men and women.



2. Myth: Bisexual Women are Really Lesbians
Fact: Some women may come out as bisexual before they come out as lesbian because either they're not really sure what they are, or they may think bisexuality is more acceptable than being a lesbian. Bisexuality can be a pathway to coming out as lesbian, but it is not always the case. Conversely, some women may come out as lesbian, but then realize that bisexuality is a more authentic identity.



3. Bisexual Women are Sexually Confused
Fact: There is a belief in both the straight and lesbian community that bisexuals cannot make up their minds which sex they want to be with. Usually it is the straight and gay people who are confused. The bisexuals know who they like: both men and women!



4. Bisexual Women are Promiscuous
Fact: Because bisexual women are attracted to both sexes, some people assume that they are more sexually promiscuous than other people. The truth is, bisexual women are as diverse as the rest of the population. Some may be having all kinds of sexual experiences, others may not have had any sexual relationships at all.



5. Bisexuals will Never Settle with one Person
Fact: Along with other myths about bisexuals is they myth that they will never settle with one sex because they will always be thinking about the other sex. The truth is bisexuals have as much ability to be monogamous as anyone.



</answer>



<answer from>



spiralof...
Member since: 24 October 2007
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>

</answer>

Jaime
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 1144 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its nothing new really. Each government since the beginning of time has mostly cared about their own agenda. I believe if the founding fathers had been alive to see how things have turned out they would be so disgusted.



The tracking of citizens, privacy invasions, lots of red tape, loss of freedom, its all contributed to this mess. There's this old quote that says that all great empires destroy themselves from within first. What we're seeing now is the decline of the American Empire.



So what you need to do is always, no matter where you live in the world, always protect yourself, don't count on your government to do it for you.



EDIT: btw I don't think Capitalism is exactly evil, its better than living in a socialist country. We need to have Capitalism because that's what freedom means, the freedom to do things even in business but we need more checks and balances so we can avoid things in the future like Enron.

<answer from>



Barrie O
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 244 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not the fact that you are 62, it is you. What is home like. I'm guessing it is pretty gross if you are so keen to get out of it. But a bicycle is not the way to go. Long trips, long roads, you are a sitting duck to get struck and killed. That's not the answer you need. Camping out by yourself can get very lonely, too. Catch a bus and go fishing for a week-end or even a couple of days mid-week. The romantic notion of camping out is all well and good, but carting all your necessary gear on a bicycle means loading up too much. Your motor will soon wear out under the weight. If your health is not up to it, nor are you.



Boredom is your only problem, I would think. Obviously you have a computer, get to a library two or three times a week to get some instruction. I should do that myself because I know bugger all about how to effectively operate my own.



And what's wrong with building up a sex life at 62? E.d.? Use Viagra.
Magic stuff. You really should think of yourself as a horny old devil. I'm 68 and I still do. It's great. Can you have a dog? Now that's a mate you would relish to have. but make sure you allow him in the house. Of course he is going to widdle inside, but they soon learn. you will need to have a doggie door added to your back door to allow him out in the middle of the night, when he wants to go out. And in while you might be absent for some hours. A small dog with short hair is ideal.
Low maintenance. they give one a source of getting above oneself.
Call him after my name.

shorty

<answer>



So I'm straight (but open minded)
And I completely understand wanting to fight for marriage.  How would you feel if you and YOUR partner weren't allowed to get married, you were just insurance sharers?  Marriage is a concept created by society that symbolizes self sacrifice for the sake of the other, of the couple.  Marriage is beautiful, selfless, based on pure love (idealistically).  Sure, you get the practical benefits of shared insurance.  But I seriously doubt that you'd feel satisfied being nothing more than an insurance sharer with the person you love, and sleep with, and raise a family with.  Plus, disallowing gay marriage SHOULD be illegal.  Private weddings, like ones led by certain religious groups or whatnot, should have the right to deny certain people marriage.  But ANYONE should be allowed to marry publicly who is of age and not related (for safety reasons), because the Constitution does not say marriage is for men with women, RELIGION does.  So why does the government have this authority? It's mixing religion with politics.



</answer>

<question from>



Latrell

</question from>



<question>



I think I'm homophobic?



I'm so homophobic that asking this question in this section makes me feel uncomfortable, I confess this because I know its wrong. I know some gay people, and I don't mind them I treat them with the utmost respect. Is this a big issue, don't tell me to see a therapist. Because I'm not a nut case, but the reality of it is, that I have nothing but love for gay women, I would even take part in........ But with gay men its like I become some prejudices A hole. What are your thoughts?, is this normal way for someone to behave?



</question>



<additional details>



@ Officer Jefferey, I most certainly don't swing that way.



</additional details>



<answer from>



SteveC is making a comeback
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 9695 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Very normal



SteveC



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks Steve. Good to have you back.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



mhatter
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Homophobia is an irrational negative reaction to Gays and Lesbians. This is similar to a racist being negatively effected by Blacks or a misogynist being hateful towards women. While I believe most people have these negative feelings towards whole groups of humans they are completely ignorant of... the obvious problem is when these negative feelings grow into outward and violent action.



A little knowledge about those whom you have negative feelings towards, but are ignorant of, would do wonders.  What is it about gay men which makes you so uncomfortable? And does it effect you directly and personally somehow?



Good luck in your journey...



</answer>



<answer from>



booger
Member since: 23 May 2007
Total points: 349 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



you know wahts weird. Im bi, and ive had boyfriends and made out with a ton of boys. And some how im homophobic. My friend always teases me. But i never get prejudice or act like a Ahole, i actually get scared or nervous around them like a phobia, and i want to get away really fast, its really weird. Personally i do NOT think its normal, you just need to open up more, and recognize that they are normal people and they just dont want to have girlfriends or wives, simple as that.



ALSO, youve been taught since little, and society has engraved in you that being gay is wrong, so you act weird when you're around it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Spookeri...
Member since: 14 May 2006
Total points: 4303 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well first the concept of "lesbians are ok and I would join in" ... well, no you wouldn't, because they're lesbians.  They don't like men.  That means they don't want to be with you.



It sounds like it all comes from insecurity about yourself.  You fear gay men, because you fear that a gay man might like you.  That's the trappings of the male ego wiggling and screaming.  Just because someone likes men, doesn't mean they like ALL men.  They, just like heterosexual women - and most people on the planet - have a thing called "standards".



Just as all women will not immediately pounce your d!ck as being god's gift to womankind, neither will a gay man do the same, thinking you are Adonis sent to earth for him to pleasure.  It just doesn't work that way.



What you need to do is see your fragile male ego for what it is, and accept people as being human freaking beings, rather than defining them by their sexuality.  That's your first step.  Come back later for step 2.



Source(s):



Me: genderqueer, bio-fem



</answer>

Grumpy old man

</answer from>



<answer>



You seem rational, and I imagine you could overcome this "phobia".  You don't need to be gay, experiment in gay sex, or anything else to get over your homophobia;  you don't need to agree with everything, or for that fact anything in gay culture, that doesn't make you a homophobe.  Look up what a phobia is.  It is a fear, and when you understand  that you have a fear of, you can overcome it.  If you "hate" the gay community, as a whole but not your friends, a logical person when understand his problem should be able to use his intelligence to overcome that.  Has someone done something personal to you?  If so, direct your fear or hate towards him!  It's easier to overcome a problem with an individual than a whole group.



And finally, perhaps learn to just not verbalize this hate or fear.  If you keep it to yourself, and each time the hate pops up, analyze why you have felt that way.  If you have no reason to hate, you will probably begin to get over it.



Thanks for the interesting question, and thanks for being concerned.



</answer>

<question from>



Angela
Member since: 17 July 2006
Total points: 25302 (Level 7)



</question from>



<question>



Online dating : Pros and Cons?



A friend who is in her 50s is interested in online dating- I don't know how to advise her as I am happily married and have not tried this. Any pros and cons from those of you who have done this?



</question>



<answer from>



Shortstuff ♥
Member since: 02 January 2007
Total points: 64275 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tell your friend to try American Singles.com for her first online experience. There are many male players out there to stay away from because they love to play games. On A.S. members can submit a photo & write a little about themselves. There are also basic questions to answer so members can read the info & see if it's someone they'd like to Instant Message via the website. It's a great way to weed out the bad apples & then see if they're interested in anyone special. If your friend joins such a website such as A.S., eHarmony, etc. tell her to be very cautious as to what she tells men about herself, family, address, financial situation, etc. Tell her it's best to get to know someone via IM's, e-mails, or phone calls before meeting. The woman always needs to meet the man on her own turf, meaning in her city, not his, & not half way. They should meet in a public place & she should never take him to her home until they have dated for quite some time. A woman has to use caution & use common sense. She also needs to tell someone (friend/family) who she is meeting & where. She leaves the restaurant  in her car & goes home, & he does the same thing. The woman must make sure he doesn't follow her home.  Again, use common sense. One can never be too cautious. People will knock these websites, especially when they have never tryed them. My ex met his current wife on A.S., as well as my brother & his new wife, & a few other of my friends. Some work out & some don't.



</answer>



<answer from>



keeprock...
Member since: 11 September 2006
Total points: 10217 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a convenient way to get to know people,especially for people who for some reason have difficulty meeting the opposite sex.They may have lost touch with their old friends and don't like going out alone; Location,Children,Illness etc.
I would think reputable dating sites try and screen prospective clients to try and minimise and risk.



There will be conmen/women out for what they can get,money,sex,but that is the same with any meeting.
Used with common sense I think the advantages of a reputable site outweigh the disadvantages.



</answer>

America is a migrant country , it was established by migrants for migrants.



the only problem that is has with this is that it is not multicultural and therefore allows ghetto's of concentrated ethic minorities to build up in the cities rather than assimilate them as equals.



The only native Americans are the original tribes that inhabited the country before white man.



Everyone else is an immigrant or descended from immigrants.



On the base of the statue of Liberty in New York is a plaque that reads; ( Given to the US by France no less)



"Not like the brazen giant of Greek fame,



With conquering limbs astride from land to land;



Here at our sea-washed, sunset hates shall stand



A mighty woman with a torch, whose flame



Is the imprisoned lighting, and her name



Mother of Exiles. From her beacon hand



Glows world-wide welcome; her mild eyes command



The air-bridged harbor that twin cities frame.



"Keep, ancient lands, your storied pomp!" cries she



With silent lips. "Give me your tired, your poor,



Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free,



The wretched refuse of your teeming shore,



Send these, the homeless, tempest-tossed to me,



I lift my lamp beside the golden door



...............That is why immigrants come to the US.



</answer>

<question>



What does the word elderly mean? When does one get there?



I don't feel old and i hate that word....



</question>



<additional details>



maybe it means when you can't  you know.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Shortstuff ♥
Member since: 02 January 2007
Total points: 64275 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I do not feel old either & I dislike that word as well. I don't refer to anyone as being "elderly."



I merely refer to him/her as being that older gentleman or that older lady/woman if they're in with a crowd of people of mixed ages.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



There are so many best answers thank all of you...



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



rhumba girl
Member since: 19 June 2006
Total points: 17271 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Senior Citizens



</answer from>



<answer>



Perhaps it would make you feel better to know the Biblical origins of the word:



Easton's 1897 Bible Dictionary
Elder



a name frequently used in the Old Testament as denoting a person clothed with authority, and entitled to respect and reverence (Gen. 50:7). It also denoted a political office (Num. 22:7). The "elders of Israel" held a rank among the people indicative of authority.
--------------------------------------...



Of course, as time has gone on, the word elderly has come to mean old, and many have stopped treating their elderly as people of authority entitled to respect.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sis
Member since: 14 November 2006
Total points: 28317 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Elderly means old and the alternative to that is dying young.



Many do die young. You can't do a thing about getting older.
You can be miserable thinking negative thoughts.



Why not focus on your many blessings & enjoy



each day doing what is good.



Today could be your last or you could decide to enjoy &
embrace each age you are. It's only a number.



You are only as old or young as you think.



Choose to smile a lot, its contagious.



Blessings to you my friend.***

Tx. Sis

kayboff

<answer>



This isn't my own. I just recieved it through the email. I think you will like it.
NEW ALPHABET



A is for apple, and B is for boat,
That used to be right, but now it won't float!
Age before beauty is what we once said,
But let's be a bit more realistic instead.



Now



The  Alphabet



A's for arthritis;
B's the bad back,
C's the chest pains, perhaps car-d-iac?



D is for dental decay and decline,
E is for eyesight, can't read that top line!
F is for fissures and fluid retention,
G is for gas which I'd rather not mention.



H is for high blood pressure -- I'd rather it low;
I is for incisions with scars you can show.
J is for joints, out of socket, won't mend,
K is for knees that crack when they bend.



L 's for libido, what happened to sex?
M is for memory, I forget what comes next.
N is neuralgia, in nerves way down low;
O is for osteo, bones that don't grow!



P for prescriptions, I have quite a few,
just give me a pill and I'll be good as new!
Q is for queasy, is it fatal or flu?
R is for reflux, one meal turns to two.



S is  for sleepless nights, counting my fears,
T is for Tinnitus; bells in my ears!
U is for urinary; troubles with flow;
V for vertigo, that's 'dizzy,' you know.



W for worry, now what's going around?
X is for X ray, and what might be found.
Y for another year I'm left here behind,
Z is for zest I still have -- in my mind.



I've survived all the symptoms, my body's deployed,



and  I'm keeping twenty-six doctors fully employed!



HAVE A GREAT DAY!



Source(s):



mdgcats



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



rangergo...
Member since: 05 January 2008
Total points: 8136 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, the government has no business denying equal rights to any person on the basis of his or her sexual orientation. That includes equal marriage rights.



In a civilized society, church and state are separate, so if a particular church chooses not to solemnize marriage between same-sex couples, the government should not force it to do so. By the same token, if a church wishes to solemnize same-sex marriages, the government should not prevent it from doing so.



In this way, the government can remain neutral.



</answer>

<answer>



I don't think you look gay. A lot of gay men end up looking buff and hypermasculine. This is because gay men are attracted to masculine features--if they were attracted to feminine features, they'd be straight.



So, no, you don't look gay to me.



You do look androgynous, which is also very cool. From an aesthetic point of view, your features are classically beautiful. You could be a model. If people at your school are making fun of you, it's because they are jealous and they fear that they're not as goodlooking as you are. There are probably a lot of girls who have a crush on you!



But you also look too young to be worrying about what a bunch of online creeps like us think of you. Please be very careful and don't reveal any personal information online.



My advice is this: You may be straight, bi or gay. You may even be trans. It doesn't have anything to do with the way other people say you look. Kids in school call each other "gay" for all kinds of reasons; mainly because everybody is totally, terribly insecure.



So ignore what people say. Tell them what you think of them, if you feel like it. They'll worry about it just as much as you did. And remember there are plenty of boys and girls in your school who will want to hang out with you, so don't worry about some jerk who you think is more "popular." Most likely, that person is the MOST insecure of all.



You have the right to determine who you are for yourself, and in your own time. There's no hurry, but once you've figured it out, don't let anybody bring you down--you have as much right to exist as anybody else.



</answer>

England is more than likely like Australia. I think they will be accepting.

"
As males have a Y chromosome and females do not, a mother’s body may be more likely to recognise a male foetus than a female one as foreign and generate a strong immune response.



Other research has shown that this response can strengthen with each subsequent male pregnancy. This may affect the way that the brain develops sexually.



“If this immune theory were correct, then the link between the mother’s immune reaction and the child’s future sexual orientation would probably be some effect of maternal anti-male antibodies on the sexual differentiation of the brain,” -Dr Bogaert

<answer>



Politicians and church leaders gain power and stay in power by creating issues that drive a wedge between people. This tactic has been used throughout history (eg: feudalism, slavery, racism, sexism, divine right of kings, witch trials, inquisition, the Crusades, so very many more). Same sex marriage is the current social issue they have latched unto since there is still a large enough portion of the population that is willing to be swayed through "biblical" arguments. Fifty year from now they'll have found something new to latch onto--hatred keeps butts in the pews, money in the collection plates and hypocrite politicians in office. Anyone who knows history should never be shocked at the ability of people in power to cling to hatred and controversy.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Many councils run a scheme for the elderly where things that help safety and security are done by volunteers, she may have to buy the door and they would fit it for her.
Phone her local council and find out if they run a similar scheme, if not, try Age Concern as they would know of any entitlement to help.

Yes. It is possible.

It's not cheap.
And it's not easy to get to that point.
You have to have psychological evaluations, hormone treatment, a support group, and months of post-op recuperation.
It's not a snap. It's a life-changing journey.
So don't speak so simply about it.

okay this was honestly HILARIOUS..
A couple of nights ago at dinner my mom starting choking. Everyone looked up [all 3 of my siblings and my father] but no one did anything. She proceeded to bang on the table, but then made a face like she was fine so everyone was like okay, cool. So then she was still choking and she looks at my dad and I'm like "Dad I think you should do something and he's like, "What do you want me to do?" hahaha. So finally my mom was all right and she's like. "Thanks a lot!" So my dad says "WHAT! What was I supposed to do?" She's like, "You could have done more than picked up your fork and continued eating!"



Lol, you may not find that funny, but to me it was the funniest thing to happen in a while.
